Addition of the labeled olefin to a yew bark extract, followed by radiochemically guided fractionation, provided sufficient product to establish the structure as taxa-4(5),11(12)-diene by two-dimensional NMR spectroscopic methods. Therefore, the first dedicated step in taxol biosynthesis is the conversion of the universal diterpenoid precursor geranylgeranyl diphosphate to taxa-4(5),11 (12)-diene, rather than to the 4(20),11(12)-diene isomer previously suggested on the basis of the abundance of taxoids with double bonds in these positions. The very common occurrence of taxane derivatives bearing the 4(20)-ene-5-oxy functional grouping, and the lack of oxygenated derivatives bearing a 4(5)-double bond, suggest that hydroxylation at C-5 of taxadiene with allylic rearrangement of the double bond is an early step in the conversion of this olefin intermediate to taxol. The highly functionalized diterpenoid taxol (paclitaxel) 1Paclitaxel is the generic name for taxol, which is now a registered trademark of Bristol-Myers Squibb. Because of the far greater familiarity with the word taxol, we use it here in lieu of “paclitaxel.” 1 (1Wani M.C. Taylor H.L. Wall M.E. Coggon P. McPhail A.T. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1971; 93: 2325-2327Crossref PubMed Scopus (3800) Google Scholar) is of interest because of its efficacy in the treatment of a range of cancers (2Holmes F.A. Kudelka A.P. Kavanagh J.J. Huber M.H. Ajani J.A. Valero V. Georg G.I. Chen T.T. Ojima I. Vyas D.M. Taxane Anticancer Agents: Basic Science and Current Status. American Chemical Society, Washington, D. C.1995: 31-57Google Scholar). A principal limitation to the wider therapeutic use of taxol was the limited supply of the drug isolated from the bark of Pacific yew (Taxus brevifolia Nutt.:Taxaceae); the yields are low (0.01-0.1% dry weight), the species is very slow growing and sparsely distributed, and the harvest is destructive (3Cragg G.M. Sander K.M. Cancer Cells. 1991; 3: 233-235PubMed Google Scholar, 4Kingston D.G.I. Pharmacol. Ther. 1991; 52: 1-34Crossref PubMed Scopus (320) Google Scholar). Alternate approaches for obtaining taxol include isolation from the renewable foliage and other tissues of plantation-grown Taxus species (5Witherup K.M. Look S.A. Stasko M.W. Ghiorzi T.J. Muschik G.M. Cragg G.M. J. Nat. Prod. 1990; 53: 1249-1255Crossref PubMed Scopus (234) Google Scholar, 6Kelsey R.G. Vance N.C. J. Nat. Prod. 1992; 55: 912-917Crossref Scopus (60) Google Scholar, 7Fett-Neto A.G. DiCosmo F. Planta Med. 1992; 58: 464-466Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar, 8Wheeler N.C. Hehnen M.T. J. Forest. 1993; 91: 15-18Google Scholar, 9Vidensek N. Lim P. Campbell A. Carlson C. J. Nat. Prod. 1990; 53: 1609-1610Crossref PubMed Scopus (177) Google Scholar, 10Wheeler N.C. Jech K. Masters S. Brobst S.W. Alvarado A.B. Hoover A.J. Snader K.M. J. Nat. Prod. 1992; 55: 432-440Crossref PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar), production in tissue culture systems (11Gibson D.M. Ketchum R.E.B. Vance N.C. Christen A.A. Plant Cell Rep. 1993; 12: 479-482Crossref PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar, 12Fett-Neto A.G. DiCosmo F. Reynolds W.F. Sakata K. Bio/Technology. 1992; 10: 1572-1575Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar), and semisynthesis of the drug and its analogs from baccatin III 2 and related late stage taxane diterpenoid (taxoid) metabolites that are more readily available (13Guénard D. Guéritte-Voegelein F. Potier P. Acc. Chem. Res. 1993; 26: 160-167Crossref Scopus (477) Google Scholar, 14Georg G.I. Ali S.M. Zygmut J. Jayasinghe L.R. Exp. Opin. Ther. Patents. 1994; 4: 109-120Crossref Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 15Nicolaou K.C. Dai W.-M. Guy R.K. Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. Engl. 1994; 33: 15-44Crossref Scopus (685) Google Scholar, 16Kingston D.G.I. George G.I. Chen T.T. Ojima I. Vyas D.M. Taxane Anticancer Agents: Basic Science and Current Status. American Chemical Society, Washington, D. C.1995: 203-216Google Scholar). Total synthesis of taxol, at present, is not commercially viable (17Borman S. Chem. Eng. News. 1994; 72: 32-34Crossref Scopus (23) Google Scholar), and efficient and economical supply of the drug must rely on biological production systems for the foreseeable future (18Cragg G.M. Schepartz S.A. Suffness M. Grever M.R. J. Nat. Prod. 1993; 56: 1657-1668Crossref PubMed Scopus (265) Google Scholar). Therefore, it is essential to understand the origin of taxol and related taxoids in yew species from the universal precursor of plant diterpenoids, geranylgeranyl diphosphate 3 (19West C.A. Porter J.W. Spurgeon S.L. Biosynthesis of Isoprenoid Compounds. Vol. 1. John Wiley & Sons, New York1981: 375-411Google Scholar). To this end, we have undertaken a systematic study of taxol biosynthesis at the enzyme level, with the goal of targeting the slow steps of the pathway for ultimate manipulation. The biosynthesis of taxol 1 (Scheme 1) is presumed to involve cyclization of geranylgeranyl diphosphate 3, via (1 S)-verticillene 4, to taxa-4(20),11(12)-diene 5 (20Harrison J.W. Scrowston R.M. Lythgoe B. J. Chem. Soc. C. 1966; : 1933-1945Crossref Scopus (60) Google Scholar, 21Begley M.J. Jackson C.B. Pattenden G. Tetrahedron. 1990; 46: 4907-4924Crossref Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 22Guéritte-Voegelein F. Guénard D. Potier P. J. Nat. Prod. 1987; 50: 9-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar) since taxoids bearing the 4(20) - and 11(12) -pair of double bonds are very common (23Kingston D.G.I. Molinero A.A. Rimoldi J.M. Prog. Chem. Org. Nat. Prod. 1993; 61: 1-206Google Scholar). Such a cyclization to establish the taxane skeleton could then be followed by oxidative elaboration of this diterpene olefin intermediate (22Guéritte-Voegelein F. Guénard D. Potier P. J. Nat. Prod. 1987; 50: 9-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 24Floss H.G. Mocek U. Suffness M. Taxol: Science and Applications. CRC Press, Boca Raton, FL1995Google Scholar). Previous investigations on taxol biosynthesis have involved feeding early precursors, such as labeled acetate, to various yew tissue preparations (25Strobel G.A. Stierle A. van Kuijk F.J.G.M. Plant Sci. 1992; 84: 65-74Crossref Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 26Zamir L.O. Nedea M.E. Garneau F.X. Tetrahedron Letts. 1992; 33: 5235-5236Crossref Scopus (52) Google Scholar), or have focused on late stage modifications to the taxane nucleus, such as the origin of appended acyl moieties (27Fleming P.E. Mocek U. Floss H.G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1993; 115: 805-807Crossref Scopus (61) Google Scholar, 28Fleming P.E. Knaggs A.R. He X.-G. Mocek U. Floss H.G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1994; 116: 4137-4138Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar). No experimental work on the enzymology of taxol biosynthesis has been reported, and the first dedicated step of the pathway and the identity of the presumed olefinic precursor of taxol have remained uncertain. In this communication, we describe the enzymatic cyclization of geranylgeranyl diphosphate to taxa-4(5),11(12) -diene as the first committed reaction, and a very slow step, of taxol biosynthesis. Two-year-old T. brevifolia saplings in active growth were obtained from the Weyerhaeuser Research Center, Centralia, WA. [1-3H]Geranylgeranyl diphosphate (118 Ci/mol) was prepared as described previously (29LaFever R.E. Stofer Vogel B. Croteau R. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 313: 139-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). Bark extracts and taxoid standards (taxol, cephalomannine, and baccatin III, and their 10-deacetyl derivatives) were obtained from Hauser Chemical Research Inc., Boulder, CO. (+)-Taxusin was isolated from the wood of T. brevifolia (30Della Casa De Marcano D.P. Halsall G. J. Chem. Soc. Chem. Commun. 1969; : 1282-1283Crossref Google Scholar). Other diterpenoid standards were from our own collection. Methods previously developed for the isolation and assay of terpenoid cyclases from conifer stem tissue were employed (29LaFever R.E. Stofer Vogel B. Croteau R. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 313: 139-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 31Lewinsohn E. Gijzen M. Savage T.J. Croteau R. Plant Physiol. 1991; 96: 38-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). Yew sapling stem sections were frozen in liquid N2and pulverized in a hammer mill to separate the bark and adhering tissue from the woody core. The resulting “bark” powder was extracted with a buffer containing vinylpyrrolidone polymers and polystyrene resin to adsorb phenolics, and the 27,000 × g supernatant was partially purified by ion-exchange chromatography on DEAE-cellulose (31Lewinsohn E. Gijzen M. Savage T.J. Croteau R. Plant Physiol. 1991; 96: 38-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). The preparation was then dialyzed to assay conditions (30 m M HEPES (pH 8.0), 5 m M dithiothreitol, 10% glycerol) and adjusted to ∼50 μg of protein/ml before incubation in the presence of 10 μM geranylgeranyl diphosphate and 1 m M MgCl2(29LaFever R.E. Stofer Vogel B. Croteau R. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 313: 139-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). Following incubation (1-3 h), the pentane-soluble products of the reaction mixture were extracted and the extract passed through a short column of silica gel to provide the hydrocarbon fraction. Quantification was by aliquot counting, and the products were analyzed by radio-GLC. 2The abbreviations used are:GLCgas-liquid chromatographyCCcolumn chromatographyDEPTdistortionless enhancement by polarization transferDQF-COSYdouble quantum filter homonuclear correlated spectroscopyHETCORheteronuclear correlationHMBCheteronuclear multiple bond correlationHMQCheteronuclear multiple quantum correlationHPLChigh pressure liquid chromatographyMSmass spectrometryTOCSYtotal correlation spectroscopy. To obtain sufficient amounts of the biosynthetic olefin for use in in vivo studies and for GLC-MS analysis, the enzyme preparation was scaled up by a factor of 10. gas-liquid chromatography column chromatography distortionless enhancement by polarization transfer double quantum filter homonuclear correlated spectroscopy heteronuclear correlation heteronuclear multiple bond correlation heteronuclear multiple quantum correlation high pressure liquid chromatography mass spectrometry total correlation spectroscopy. The biosynthetic olefin (5.36 μCi of 3H) that had been purified by CC (silica gel; pentane) and argentation TLC (silica gel; 10% AgNO3:pentane) was suspended by sonication in a buffer (1.5 ml) consisting of 5 m M KH2PO4(pH 5.5), 10 m M sucrose, 2 m M KCl, 2 m M phenylalanine, 1 m M dithiothreitol, 1 m M MgCl2, 1 m M sodium acetate, 1 m M sodium benzoate, 0.2 m M EDTA, 0.1 m M Na2H2P2O7, and 0.05% Tween 20. Following filter sterilization, the suspension was split and vacuum-infiltrated (six times) into two 1.75-g batches of yew stem discs (1-2 mm thick) prepared from sapling stem sections that had been surface-sterilized in 70% ethanol (1 s), followed by 3% sodium hypochlorite, 0.5% Tween 20 (1 min) and washing, and then sectioned using sterile technique. The tissue was incubated for 8 days at room temperature, in air, in the light with slow shaking in a glass vial and then thoroughly extracted with hexane (2 × 10 ml), which was passed through a silica gel column that was rinsed with diethyl ether:pentane (1:1) to remove residual substrate and labeled metabolites less polar than (+)-taxusin. The column was then rinsed with 10 ml of chloroform:acetonitrile:methanol (6:3:1), and this material was used to extract the tissue, as before. The process was repeated with three additional portions of chloroform:acetonitrile:methanol, at which point a methanol extraction afforded no additional extracted radioactivity. This taxoid fraction was decolorized, without loss of tritium, by elution through Davisil (Alltech C18on silica) with a gradient from 55% water, 25% methanol, 20% acetonitrile to 100% acetonitrile. Approximately 90% of the applied tracer was recovered in organic solvent-soluble products. Aliquots of the taxoid fraction were analyzed by HPLC on a 250 mm × 4.6-mm Econosil C8 column (5 μm, Alltech) by gradient elution (30 ml) from solvent A (55% water, 25% methanol, 20% acetonite) to 75% solvent A plus 25% solvent B (acetonitrile), while collecting 1-ml fractions for liquid scintillation counting. Retention times of the standards were as follows: 10-deacetylbaccatin III (3.08 min), baccatin III (5.24 min), 10-deacetylcephalomannine (20.48 min), 10-deacetyltaxol (22.99 min), cephalomannine (26.21 min), and taxol (27.82 min). The taxoid fraction was subsequently diluted with 2 mg each of 10-deacetylbaccatin III, cephalomannine, and taxol and subjected to preparative TLC on silica gel G with chloroform:methanol (20:1). The products (10-deacetylbaccatin III, RF 0.17; cephalomannine plus taxol, RF 0.47-0.51) were eluted with methanol, diluted with an additional 200 mg of authentic carrier, and crystallized from aqueous methanol to constant specific activity and m.p. Because cephalomannine and taxol were not separable, the eluted mixture was split in half; one-half was diluted with cephalomannine, the other with taxol. Repeated crystallization gave 10-deacetylbaccatin III, 150 nCi/mmol, m.p. 243−245°C decomposes cephalomannine, 14.0 nCi/mmol, m.p. 183−186°C decomposes taxol, 31.7 nCi/mmol, m.p. 215−218°C decomposes. All m.p. values are in agreement with the literature (23Kingston D.G.I. Molinero A.A. Rimoldi J.M. Prog. Chem. Org. Nat. Prod. 1993; 61: 1-206Google Scholar). An extract from 750 kg of T. brevifolia bark powder, that had been enriched in non-polar materials by partitioning from methanol into heptane, was batch processed through silica gel with hexane to afford a hydrocarbon fraction (3.1 g). This material was diluted with 0.5 μCi of the enzymatically prepared olefin and chromatographed repeatedly on a silica gel column with hexane, while monitoring fractions by liquid scintillation counting and GLC-MS, to yield a fraction (230 mg; >90% recovery of label) eluting between sandaracopimaradiene and abietatriene. This material, a very complex mixture of sesquiterpene and diterpene hydrocarbons, was next purified by argentation column chromatography (10% AgNO3-silica gel with a 0 to 10% gradient of Et2O in pentane) to afford 72 mg of an oil. Another passage through silica gel (with pentane) followed by reversed-phase column chromatography on Davisil (Alltech C18on silica, 2.5-20% CCl4in acetonitrile) and argentation TLC (10% AgNO3-silica gel with 5% ether in pentane) yielded about 1 mg of 85% taxadiene (RF 0.8-0.9, with 2% mixed sesquiterpene olefins and 11% abietatriene). NMR spectra were recorded at 499.8 MHz (1H, DQF-COSY, TOCSY) and at 125.7 MHz (13C(1H), DEPT, HETCOR) on a Varian VXR-500S instrument, and at 300.1 MHz (HMQC, HMBC) using a Bruker AMX-300 instrument. All experiments were run at ambient temperature (21°C) with a 5 μM solution in CDCl3. Chemical shifts are reported in δ (ppm) using tetramethylsilane as an internal standard. The DQF-COSY (32Piatini U. Soerenson O.W. Ernst R.R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1982; 104: 6800-6801Crossref Scopus (1888) Google Scholar) and TOCSY (33Griesinger C. Otting G. Wuetrich K. Ernst R.R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1988; 110: 7870-7872Crossref Scopus (1199) Google Scholar) experiments (mixing time 60 ms) were run in the phase sensitive mode. The 512 t1increments of 96 scans each were sampled in 2000 data points for each of the 512 t1increments. Zero-filling the F1 domain to 2000 and a Gaussian weighting function were applied in both F1and F2domains prior to double Fourier transformation. The HETCOR (34Bax A. Morris G.A. J. Magn. Reson. 1981; 42: 501-505Google Scholar) spectrum was obtained using 2000 data points in the F2domain and 256 t1increments (800 scans each), which were zero-filled to 1000 in the F1domain. A sine-bell squared weighting function phase shifted by π/2 was applied in both domains prior to double Fourier transformation. The HMQC spectrum was measured employing the pulse sequence of Bax et al. (35Bax A. Griffey R.H. Hawkins B.L. J. Magn. Reson. 1983; 55: 301-315Google Scholar). Delay Δ was set to 3.571 ms corresponding to the average one bond carbon-proton coupling constant, 145 Hz. In this experiment, 256 t1increments were sampled in 2000 data points using 464 scans for each of the t1increments. Data in the F1domain were zero-filled to 1000, and the sine-bell squared weighting function phase shifted by π/2 was applied in both F1and F2domains prior to double Fourier transformation. Analogous parameters were adopted for the HMBC spectrum that was obtained using the pulse sequence of Bax and Summers (36Bax A. Summers M.F. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1986; 108: 2093-2094Crossref Scopus (3274) Google Scholar) and involved low-pass J-filtering to suppress correlations due to one-bond couplings. Delay Δ2was set to 62.5 ms corresponding to the average long range (through two or three bonds) carbon-proton coupling constant, 8 Hz. Radio-GLC was performed on a Gow-Mac 550P gas chromatograph coupled to a Packard 894 gas proportional counter (37Satterwhite D.M. Croteau R. J. Chromatogr. 1988; 452: 61-73Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar) using a 30 m × 0.53-mm diameter fused silica column coated with a 1.2-μm film of Superox FA (Alltech); 8 p.s.i. He, isothermal at 200°C with injector and detector at 220°C. GLC-MS analysis was performed on a Hewlett-Packard 5840A/5985B system using a 30 m × 0.25-mm diameter fused silica column with 0.25-μm film of Superox FA (Alltech) operated at 10 p.s.i. H2and programmed from 100°C (5-min hold) at 10°C/min to 220°C. Electron impact spectra were recorded at 70 eV. Pacific yew saplings were chosen as an experimental system because the taxoid content of immature tissue is relatively high (9Vidensek N. Lim P. Campbell A. Carlson C. J. Nat. Prod. 1990; 53: 1609-1610Crossref PubMed Scopus (177) Google Scholar), sapling stems contain a high proportion of phloem parenchyma cells in which taxol is thought to be produced (25Strobel G.A. Stierle A. van Kuijk F.J.G.M. Plant Sci. 1992; 84: 65-74Crossref Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 38Ellis, D., Zeldin, E., Russin, W., Brodhagen, M., Evert, R., McCown, B., (1993) Proceedings of the International Yew Research Conference, (Native Yew Conservation Council), Berkeley, CA, March 12-13, 1993.Google Scholar, 39Strobel G.A. Stierle A. Hess W.M. Plant Sci. 1993; 92: 1-12Crossref Scopus (28) Google Scholar), and saplings can be maintained in a greenhouse to minimize the effects of environmental variation (10Wheeler N.C. Jech K. Masters S. Brobst S.W. Alvarado A.B. Hoover A.J. Snader K.M. J. Nat. Prod. 1992; 55: 432-440Crossref PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar, 40Vance N.C. Kelsey R.G. Sabin T.E. Phytochemistry. 1994; 36: 1241-1244Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). A soluble enzyme extract was prepared from T. brevifolia stem sections by methods previously developed for the isolation of other terpenoid cyclases from gymnosperm stem that minimize the deleterious effects of co-extracted phenolic materials (31Lewinsohn E. Gijzen M. Savage T.J. Croteau R. Plant Physiol. 1991; 96: 38-43Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). Incubation of this preparation with 10 μM [1-3H]geranylgeranyl diphosphate, in the presence of 1 m M MgCl2, yielded radiolabeled, pentane-soluble products that were purified by column chromatography on silica gel to afford the hydrocarbon fraction (1 nmol; 5% conversion in 1 h). The production of the hydrocarbon material from geranylgeranyl diphosphate by the enzyme preparation was absolutely dependent on the presence of the divalent metal ion, as expected for a terpenoid cyclase (41Alonso W.R. Croteau R. Methods Plant Biochem. 1993; 9: 239-260Google Scholar), and negligible activity was observed in thermally inactivated control incubations. Radio-GLC analysis of the hydrocarbon fraction revealed the presence of a single major component that eluted between the tricyclic diterpene olefin standards sandaracopimaradiene and abietatriene (Fig. 1 a). To determine if this presumptive diterpene olefin could serve as a precursor of taxol, the purified biosynthetic product (5.36 μCi) was suspended in buffer and vacuum-infiltrated into two batches of T. brevifolia stem discs. Following incubation for 8 days, the labeled products were extracted and separated into a taxoid fraction containing metabolites more polar than (+)-taxusin (the tetraacetate of taxa-4(20), 11(12) -dien-5,9,10,13-tetraol). This fraction represented about 30% incorporation of radioactivity from the olefin and, when separated by reversed-phase radio-HPLC, revealed the presence of at least a dozen labeled compounds of polarity between 10-deacetylbaccatin III (10-deacetyl 2, Rt 3.08 min) and taxol 1 (Rt 27.82 min), including the common bark taxoids baccatin III 2, cephalomannine 6, and taxol, and their 10-deacetyl derivatives (40Vance N.C. Kelsey R.G. Sabin T.E. Phytochemistry. 1994; 36: 1241-1244Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar) (Scheme 1). Negligible incorporation of olefin label into this taxoid fraction was observed in control experiments with thermally inactivated tissue. To confirm the identity of the labeled taxoids, 10-deacetylbaccatin III, cephalomannine, and taxol (for which substantial amounts of authentic standards were available) were isolated by TLC, diluted with the corresponding unlabeled carrier, and crystallized to constant specific activity and melting point, thereby verifying the incorporation of the tritium-labeled olefin into 10-deacetylbaccatin III (4.1%), cephalomannine (0.5%), and taxol (1.1%). (The incorporation percentages should be regarded as minimum levels, as some tritium label (depending on the kinetic isotope effect) will be lost on oxidation at C-2 (Scheme 1) of the taxane skeleton of these advanced metabolites.) It is not uncommon for the level of 10-deacetylbaccatin III to exceed the levels of taxol and cephalomannine in T. brevifolia stem tissue (40Vance N.C. Kelsey R.G. Sabin T.E. Phytochemistry. 1994; 36: 1241-1244Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). These results indicated that the diterpene olefin product of the cell-free system did serve as a precursor of taxol and other very closely related taxoids of yew stem, thus suggesting that the cyclization product of geranylgeranyl diphosphate was a taxadiene. To identify the biosynthetic diterpene olefin product, it was necessary to acquire sufficient material for spectroscopic analysis. To this end, the hydrocarbon fraction from an extract of 750 kg of dried T. brevifolia bark powder was diluted with 0.5 μCi of the enzymatically derived, tritium-labeled olefin, and the corresponding product (∼1 mg) was isolated by radiochemically guided chromatographic fractionation. The mass spectrum of the product gave principal ions at m/z 122 (100%), 107 (26%), 121 (25%), 123 (20%), and 105 (10%), and a parent ion at m/z 272 (1.5%) consistent with a cyclic diterpene olefin of molecular formula C20H32. Radio-GLC analysis of the isolated product demonstrated coincidental elution of radioactivity and the principal mass peak, as expected. Based on recovery, it was estimated that the level of this olefin in bark tissue was in the 5-10 μg/kg range. The structure of the diterpene olefin was determined to be taxa-4(5), 11(12) -diene 7 by analysis of one- and two-dimensional 1H and 13C NMR spectra. Proton connectivities were determined by DQF-COSY and TOCSY experiments, and the signals of all carbons with directly attached protons were assigned using HETCOR and HMQC spectra. Finally, the HMBC spectrum was used to assign quaternary carbons and to check the correctness of the connectivities established by the interpretation of the other spectra. The 13C DEPT experiment revealed a total of 20 carbon resonances (Table I), of which five corresponded to methyl carbons, seven to methylene carbons, three to methine carbons, and five to non-proton bearing carbons. One of the methine resonances and three non-proton bearing carbon resonances occurred in the downfield region: 120.0-140.0 ppm. All remaining carbon resonances were in the high field region: 20.0-45.0 ppm.Table I:1H and 13C NMR chemical shifts δ (ppm) for taxa-4(5),11(12)-diene measured in CDCl3solution at 293 K with tetramethylsilane as internal standard The 1H NMR spectrum (Table I) showed a one-proton multiplet (∑J = 11.1 Hz) at δ 5.28. All other signals were in the region from 0.65 to 2.63 ppm. In the TOCSY spectrum, the olefinic CH-5 (δ 5.28) proton multiplet exhibited cross-peaks to four different sets of protons corresponding to the methylene CH2-6 (δ 1.88, 2.01) and CH2-7 (δ 1.18, 1.67) protons, the methine CH-3 (δ 2.51) proton, and the methyl CH3-20 (δ 1.68) protons. By analyzing the HETCOR spectrum, the carbon signals at δ 24.0, 38.4, 39.7, and 121.1 were assigned to C-20, C-7, C-3, and C-5, respectively; they correlated with the corresponding proton signals (see above). The resonances of the C-3 and C-7 carbons showed a cross-peak with the proton singlet at δ 0.82 in the HMBC spectrum. Therefore, the proton signal was assigned to the methyl CH3-19 protons. Additionally, this proton resonance (δ 0.82) correlated with another two carbon signals at δ37.2 and 41.4, corresponding to the quaternary C-8 and methylene CH2-9 carbons, respectively. That the signal at δ37.2 belonged to a quaternary carbon, and the signal at δ 41.4 to a methylene carbon, was further supported by the DEPT data. Analysis of the HMBC spectrum also allowed the carbon signal at δ 138.5 to be assigned to the olefinic C-4 carbon, as it exhibited a cross-peak with the methyl CH3-20 proton signal (δ 1.68) due to a two-bond linkage. The methylene CH2-9 proton signals at δ 1.42 and 1.82 were identified based upon their correlation with the C-9 carbon signal at δ 41.4 in the HETCOR spectrum. Following the interpretation of the TOCSY and DQF-COSY spectra, the methylene CH2-2 and CH2-10 proton signals were assigned. The CH-3 proton signal (δ 2.51) displayed two cross-peaks at δ 1.57 and 1.66, corresponding to the methylene CH2-2 protons. One of the CH2-9 proton signals (δ 1.42) correlated with the signal at δ2.15, and the other signal (δ 1.82) showed a cross-peak at δ2.61. Therefore, both signals at δ2.15 and 2.61 were assigned to the methylene CH2-10 protons. Moreover, they exhibited a mutual cross-peak due to geminal coupling. In addition, both correlated with the carbon signal at δ24.5 in the HETCOR spectrum. Consequently, the latter was assigned to the C-10 carbon. The HETCOR analysis also allowed the carbon signal at δ28.4 to be assigned to the C-2 carbon. The gem-dimethyl groups (CH3-16, CH3-17) attached to the quaternary C-15 carbon of the taxadiene A-ring were easily identified in the HMBC spectrum. Both methyl proton resonances at δ 1.01 (CH3-16) and 1.33 (CH3-17) displayed cross-peaks with the same carbon signals at δ 44.2, 137.7, and 39.0, corresponding to the carbons C-1, C-11, and C-15, respectively. Furthermore, the CH3-16 proton resonance correlated with the carbon CH3-17 signal at δ26.3 (assigned using HETCOR analysis) and, due to the same three-bond coupling, the proton signal of the methyl CH3-17 correlated with the carbon CH3-16 resonance at δ30.7 (assignment based on HETCOR analysis). HMBC analysis also revealed the correlation of the carbon C-11 resonance with the proton singlet at δ 1.66. At the same time, this proton resonance exhibited cross-peaks with the carbon signals at δ 29.8 and 129.5. These facts allowed assignment of the proton resonance at δ 1.66 to the methyl CH3-18 protons; the carbon signals were assigned as the methylene CH2-13 carbon (δ 29.8) and the olefinic carbon C-12 (δ 129.5). Having established the carbon resonances of the methine CH-1 and methylene CH2-13, the HETCOR analysis permitted assignment of the proton signals of the groups at δ 1.74 (CH-1), and at δ 1.88 and 2.08 (CH2-13). Both the methylene CH2-13 proton resonances, as well as the methine CH-1 proton resonance, exhibited cross-peaks at δ 1.59 and 2.08 in the DQF-COSY spectrum. At the same time, these two proton signals (δ 1.59, 2.08) showed a mutual cross-peak. Therefore, they were assigned to the methylene CH2-14 protons. Only one of the CH2-14 proton resonances displayed a cross-peak with the carbon signal at δ 22.6 in the HETCOR spectrum. However, this signal (δ 22.6) corresponded to a methylene carbon based upon the DEPT data and was assigned to C-14. The remaining unassigned methylene carbon resonance at δ 23.2 was then assigned to the methylene CH2-6, even though no cross-peak between protons and carbon of the CH2-6 group could be identified in the HETCOR and HMQC spectra. The assignment of each carbon and hydrogen of the C20H32 olefin left little doubt that the product was taxa-4(5), 11(20) -diene 7. To confirm that the biosynthetic product generated in yew stem extracts and the olefin isolated from bark were the same, large scale enzyme incubations with geranylgeranyl diphosphate were carried out and the olefin fraction was analyzed by combined GLC-MS. The retention time and mass spectrum of the enzymatic product (>99% pure) were identical to those of taxa-4(5), 11(12) -diene isolated from the bark extract (Fig. 1, b and c). (1 S)-Verticillene 4, a possible enzyme-bound intermediate in the cyclization, was not detectable as a product of the cell-free extract. The cyclization of geranylgeranyl diphosphate to taxa-4(5),11(12) -diene, as the first dedicated step in the biosynthesis of taxol and related metabolites, is consistent with earlier suggestions that the pathway involves preliminary formation of a parent taxane olefin followed by oxidative modification (20Harrison J.W. Scrowston R.M. Lythgoe B. J. Chem. Soc. C. 1966; : 1933-1945Crossref Scopus (60) Google Scholar, 21Begley M.J. Jackson C.B. Pattenden G. Tetrahedron. 1990; 46: 4907-4924Crossref Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 22Guéritte-Voegelein F. Guénard D. Potier P. J. Nat. Prod. 1987; 50: 9-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). However, the identification of taxa-4(5), 11(12) -diene 7 as the olefinic intermediate, rather than taxa-4(20), 11(12) -diene 5 as originally proposed on the basis of metabolite co-occurrence (22Guéritte-Voegelein F. Guénard D. Potier P. J. Nat. Prod. 1987; 50: 9-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar), was unexpected. Consequently, the previously proposed cyclization to 5 (20Harrison J.W. Scrowston R.M. Lythgoe B. J. Chem. Soc. C. 1966; : 1933-1945Crossref Scopus (60) Google Scholar, 21Begley M.J. Jackson C.B. Pattenden G. Tetrahedron. 1990; 46: 4907-4924Crossref Scopus (42) Google Scholar) (Scheme 1) can be reformulated as involving ionization of the geranylgeranyl diphosphate ester with closure of the first ring and deprotonation to afford (1 S)-verticillene. Protonation at C-7 can then initiate transannular cyclization to generate the taxenyl cation, which upon deprotonation at C-5 yields the endocyclic double bond of the taxadiene product. The next step of the pathway to taxol is presumed to involve oxygenation of taxadiene (22Guéritte-Voegelein F. Guénard D. Potier P. J. Nat. Prod. 1987; 50: 9-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 24Floss H.G. Mocek U. Suffness M. Taxol: Science and Applications. CRC Press, Boca Raton, FL1995Google Scholar). The observations that no oxygenated taxoids bearing the 4(5) -double bond have yet been reported, whereas taxoids with the exo-methylene at the 4(20) -position and that also bear an oxygen function at C-5 are exceedingly common (23Kingston D.G.I. Molinero A.A. Rimoldi J.M. Prog. Chem. Org. Nat. Prod. 1993; 61: 1-206Google Scholar), therefore suggest that hydroxylation at C-5 of taxa-4(5),11(12) -diene, with migration of the double bond, must occur as an early, if not the first, oxygenation step of the pathway (Scheme 2). The transformation of taxa-4(5), 11(12) -diene 7 to taxa-4(20), 11(12) -diene-5-ol 8 would also set the stage for the later elaboration of the unusual oxetane moiety 11, which is considered (22Guéritte-Voegelein F. Guénard D. Potier P. J. Nat. Prod. 1987; 50: 9-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 24Floss H.G. Mocek U. Suffness M. Taxol: Science and Applications. CRC Press, Boca Raton, FL1995Google Scholar) to arise by conversion of the 5-hydroxy-4(20) -methylene 9 to the corresponding epoxide function 10 followed by ring expansion (Scheme 2). Although the enzyme that catalyzes the transformation of geranylgeranyl diphosphate to taxadiene has not yet been characterized in any detail, the low cyclization activity in T. brevifolia stem extracts relative to that of other diterpene cyclases of gymnosperm stem tissue (29LaFever R.E. Stofer Vogel B. Croteau R. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 313: 139-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar), coupled to the very low levels of this key olefin intermediate in the bark, suggest that the cyclization step to generate the taxane skeleton is very slow (relative to subsequent oxygenations) and, thus, is an important target for manipulation. With the initial step of taxol biosynthesis in Pacific yew now defined, it would be of interest to determine if the taxol-producing fungus Taxomyces andreanae (42Stierle A. Strobel G. Stierle D. Science. 1993; 260: 214-216Crossref PubMed Scopus (1431) Google Scholar) employs a similar cyclization reaction. We thank David Bailey (Hauser Chemical Research Inc., Boulder, CO) for the bark extract and authentic taxoid standards, Nicholas Wheeler (Weyerhaeuser Research Center, Centralia, WA) for the T. brevifolia saplings, and Gerald Pattenden (University of Nottingham, Nottingham, United Kingdom) for the mass spectrum of verticillene.

The ligand binding affinities of the integrins are regulated through their cytoplasmic domains. To identify specific residues that are involved in this process, we have generated mutants in the β1and β3tails and coexpressed them in Chinese hamster ovary cells with constitutively active α subunits. These α subunits are chimera of extracellular and transmembrane αIIbjoined to the cytoplasmic domains of α5, α6A, or α6Band confer an energy-dependent high affinity state when expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells. The affinity state of these transfectants was determined by analyzing the binding of PAC1, an antibody that specifically recognizes the activated form of the reporter group, extracellualar αIIbβ3. We have identified point mutants in several areas of the β tails, which result in a reduced ability to bind ligand. Complete abolition of PAC1 binding was obtained with mutants in an NP XY motif found in many integrin β subunits and implicated in the internalization of other cell surface receptors. Similar effects on PAC1 binding were observed whether coexpression was with α chimera containing α5, α6A, or α6Bcytoplasmic sequences. These studies identify a novel role for the NP XY motif in the regulation of integrin binding affinity. The ligand binding affinities of the integrins are regulated through their cytoplasmic domains. To identify specific residues that are involved in this process, we have generated mutants in the β1and β3tails and coexpressed them in Chinese hamster ovary cells with constitutively active α subunits. These α subunits are chimera of extracellular and transmembrane αIIbjoined to the cytoplasmic domains of α5, α6A, or α6Band confer an energy-dependent high affinity state when expressed in Chinese hamster ovary cells. The affinity state of these transfectants was determined by analyzing the binding of PAC1, an antibody that specifically recognizes the activated form of the reporter group, extracellualar αIIbβ3. We have identified point mutants in several areas of the β tails, which result in a reduced ability to bind ligand. Complete abolition of PAC1 binding was obtained with mutants in an NP XY motif found in many integrin β subunits and implicated in the internalization of other cell surface receptors. Similar effects on PAC1 binding were observed whether coexpression was with α chimera containing α5, α6A, or α6Bcytoplasmic sequences. These studies identify a novel role for the NP XY motif in the regulation of integrin binding affinity. The regulated adhesion of cells to each other or to elements in the extracellular environment is crucial in normal physiology. The integrins, a widely distributed family of α,β heterodimers (1Hynes R.O. Cell. 1992; 69: 11-25Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (9002) Google Scholar), mediate many of these events. Members of this family are characterized by an ability to dynamically regulate their ligand binding affinity. In a process termed “activation” or “inside-out signaling,” integrins change extracellular conformation and alter ligand binding affinity and cellular adhesion (1Hynes R.O. Cell. 1992; 69: 11-25Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (9002) Google Scholar). Following ligand binding, events are triggered inside the cell. “Outside-in signaling” events include changes in cell shape, integrin localization, intracellular pH, induction of protein phosphorylation, and gene transcription (1Hynes R.O. Cell. 1992; 69: 11-25Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (9002) Google Scholar). The cytoplasmic sequences of the integrins appear to be involved in these bi-directional signaling events. Indeed, several functions have been associated with the β subunit cytoplasmic domain. For instance, these sequences contain sufficient information for specifying localization to focal adhesions (2LaFlamme S.E. Thomas L.A. Yamada S.S. Yamada K.M. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 126: 1287-1298Crossref PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar, 3LaFlamme S.E. Akiyama S.K. Yamada K.M. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 117: 437-447Crossref PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar), are required for cellular adhesion (4Hayashi Y. Haimovich B. Reszka A. Boettiger D. Horwitz A. J. Cell Biol. 1990; 110: 75-184Crossref Scopus (188) Google Scholar, 5Hibbs M.L. Jakes S. Stacker S.A. Wallace R.W. Springer T.A. J. Exp. Med. 1991; 174: 1227-1238Crossref PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar, 6Crowe D.T. Chiu H. Fong S. Weissman I.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 14411-14418Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and are capable of associating with the cytoskeletal proteins α-actinin (7Otey C.A. Vasquez G.B. Burridge K. Erickson B.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 21193-21197Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and talin (8Horwitz A. Duggan K. Buck C. Beckerle M.C. Burridge K. Nature. 1986; 320: 531-533Crossref PubMed Scopus (824) Google Scholar). Independent expression of β tails results in an inhibition of endogenous integrin function in matrix assembly, cell spreading, and cell migration (2LaFlamme S.E. Thomas L.A. Yamada S.S. Yamada K.M. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 126: 1287-1298Crossref PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar, 9Luskashev M.E. Sheppard D. Pytela R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 18311-18314Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, β cytoplasmic domains have copies of an internalization sequence, NP XY (10Chen W.-J. Goldstein J.L. Brown M.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 3116-3123Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and several residues that are potential phosphorylation sites. The functional properties of α subunit cytoplasmic sequences are less well defined. Nevertheless, these domains limit the cellular localization of integrins (11Ylanne J. Chen Y. O'Toole T.E. Loftus J.C. Takada Y. Ginsberg M.H. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 122: 223-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar, 12Briesewitz R. Kern A. Marcantonio E.E. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1993; 4: 593-604Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar, 13Kawaguchi S. Bergelson J.M. Finberg R.W. Hemler M.E. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1994; 5: 977-998Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar) and play a role in cellular adhesion, migration, and collagen gel contraction (14Shaw L.M. Mercurio A.M. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 123: 1017-1025Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 15Kassner P.D. Hemler M.E. J. Exp. Med. 1993; 178: 649-660Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 16Kawaguchi S. Hemler M.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16279-16285Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Bauer J.S. Varner J. Schreiner C. Kornberg L. Nicholas R. Juliano R.L. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 122: 209-221Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 18Chan B.M.C. Kassner P.D. Schiro J.A. Byers R. Kupper T.S. Hemler M.E. Cell. 1992; 68: 1051-1060Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar, 19Filardo E.J. Cheresh D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 269: 4641-4647Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar). Mounting evidence implicates a role for both α and β cytoplasmic domains in inside-out signaling and the maintenance of high affinity binding. The identity of the α tail determines the affinity state of recombinant integrins expressed in heterologous cells (20O'Toole T.E. Katagiri Y. Faull R.J. Peter K. Tamura R. Quaranta V. Loftus J.C. Shattil S.J. Ginsberg M.H. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 124: 1047-1059Crossref PubMed Scopus (578) Google Scholar, 21O'Toole T.E. Mandelman D. Forsyth J. Shattil S.J. Plow E.F. Ginsberg M.H. Science. 1991; 254: 845-847Crossref PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar), while deletion of these sequences disrupts cellular adhesion (14Shaw L.M. Mercurio A.M. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 123: 1017-1025Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 15Kassner P.D. Hemler M.E. J. Exp. Med. 1993; 178: 649-660Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 16Kawaguchi S. Hemler M.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 16279-16285Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Bauer J.S. Varner J. Schreiner C. Kornberg L. Nicholas R. Juliano R.L. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 122: 209-221Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 19Filardo E.J. Cheresh D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 269: 4641-4647Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar). On the other hand, a point mutation in the β3tail has been associated with an activation defect of αIIbβ3both in vivo (22Chen Y.-P. Djaffar I. Pidard D. Steiner B. Cieutat A.-M. Caen J. Rosa J.-P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10169-10173Crossref PubMed Scopus (218) Google Scholar) and in a recombinant system (20O'Toole T.E. Katagiri Y. Faull R.J. Peter K. Tamura R. Quaranta V. Loftus J.C. Shattil S.J. Ginsberg M.H. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 124: 1047-1059Crossref PubMed Scopus (578) Google Scholar). Furthermore, independent coexpression of the β, but not the α, cytoplasmic domain can abolish ligand binding by constitutively active, transfected integrins (23Chen Y.-P. O'Toole T.E. Shipley T. Forsyth J. LaFlamme S.E. Yamada K.M. Shattil S.J. Ginsberg M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 18307-18310Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Little is known regarding specific α or β cytoplasmic residues required for high affinity binding or how these relate to other functional areas in these domains. To map these sequences in the β subunit, we have mutagenized the β1and β3tails, joined them onto extracellular and transmembrane β3, and coexpressed these variants with αIIbcytoplasmic chimeras that confer constitutive ligand binding properties (20O'Toole T.E. Katagiri Y. Faull R.J. Peter K. Tamura R. Quaranta V. Loftus J.C. Shattil S.J. Ginsberg M.H. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 124: 1047-1059Crossref PubMed Scopus (578) Google Scholar). The affinity state of these transfectants was determined by analyzing their ability to bind PAC1 (24Shattil S.J. Hoxie J.A. Cunningham M. Brass L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 11107-11114Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), a monoclonal antibody that specifically recognizes the active conformation of the reporter group, αIIbβ3. Our results have identified several residues whose substitution reduces constitutive ligand binding. Complete abolition of PAC1 binding was observed with variants in an NP XY sequence. This role in affinity modulation identifies a novel function for this motif. Furthermore, these studies discount a role for phosphorylation of integrin tails in the regulation of binding affinity and suggest cytoplasmic splice variants which lack these sequence elements may be unresponsive to normal inside-out signaling pathways. Shattil S.J. Ginsberg M.H. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 124: 1047-1059Crossref PubMed Scopus (578) Google Scholar, 24Shattil S.J. Hoxie J.A. Cunningham M. Brass L.F. J. Biol. Oligonucleotides were synthesized on a model 391 DNA synthesizer (Applied Biosystems Inc.). Restriction endonucleases, TaqI polymerase, and other enzymes were from Boehringer Mannheim. The generation of several wild type (β3), chimeric (β3β1, αIIbα5, αIIbα6A, αIIbα6B), or mutant (β3Δ724, β3S752P) integrin constructs has been described previously (20O'Toole T.E. Katagiri Y. Faull R.J. Peter K. Tamura R. Quaranta V. Loftus J.C. Shattil S.J. Ginsberg M.H. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 124: 1047-1059Crossref PubMed Scopus (578) Google Scholar, 21O'Toole T.E. Mandelman D. Forsyth J. Shattil S.J. Plow E.F. Ginsberg M.H. Science. 1991; 254: 845-847Crossref PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar, 27O'Toole T.E. Loftus J.C. Plow E.F. Glass A.A. Harper J.R. Ginsberg M.H. Blood. 1989; 74: 14-18Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Additional β chimera were made by exchanging mutant β1cytoplasmic domains for those from wild type β3. Sequences encoding the β1mutants S790M, T793V/T794V, and N797I were recovered by HindIII digestion of the appropriate pRneo constructs (28Reszka A.A. Yokichi Y. Horwitz A.F. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 117: 1321-1330Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar) and ligated into HindIII-cut pCDM8 (Invitrogen, San Diego, CA). These vectors were then digested with BspHI and DraIII, and the fragment containing β1cytoplasmic sequences was ligated to a corresponding BspHI- DraIII fragment from CD3a (27O'Toole T.E. Loftus J.C. Plow E.F. Glass A.A. Harper J.R. Ginsberg M.H. Blood. 1989; 74: 14-18Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) containing β3transmembrane and extracellular domains. Cytoplasmic sequences encoding the β1variants F771L, E774V, N785I, Y788A, YTRF, S790D, Y800F, and Y800A were first amplified by the polymerase chain reaction with the 5′ oligonucleotide: GTAAAATCACTGCAGTTTGCCCTA, and the 3′ oligonucleotide: TTGATTTGGAAGCTTCTGATGATC. Amplified fragments were digested with HindIII and PstI and ligated into HindIII- and PstI-digested pCDM8. These constructs were then digested with BspHI and DraIII and ligated as above to a corresponding BspHI- DraIII fragment from CD3a. The Y788F variant of β1was generated in a two-step polymerase chain reaction strategy. Overlapping fragments containing the desired amino acid substitution were first generated in two amplifications on wild type β1sequences using the oligonucleotide pairs: GGTGAAAATCCTATTTTTAAGAGTGCCG-GTAAGGTTCCTTCACAAAGAT and CGGCACTCTTAAAAATAGGATTTTCACC-ATACCTGCAACCGTTACTGCC. The amplified fragments were combined, denatured at 85°C for 10 min, and allowed to cool to room temp. The ends were then filled in with Sequenase (29Maniatis T. Fritsch E.F. Sambrook J. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar), and double-stranded fragments amplified with the oligonucleotides: GTAAGGTTCCTTCACAAAGAT and ATACCTGCAACCGTTACTGCC. Amplified products were digested with AflII and XhoI and inserted into the AflII- XhoI-digested β3β1chimera, thereby replacing wild type cytoplasmic sequences with the mutant sequence. The β3cytoplasmic variants F727A/F730L/E733V, Y747A, S752A, and Y759A were generated in a two-step polymerase chain reaction strategy as above for the β1variant Y788F. The final amplified product was digested with MluI and XhoI and then ligated into pCDM8. These constructs were then linearized with MluI and ligated to an MluI fragment from CD3a containing the remainder of β3coding sequences. The β3B construct was made by polymerase chain reaction amplification with the oligonucleotides: CGAAAAGAATTCGCTAAATTTGAGGAAGAACGCGCCAGAGCAAAATGGGACACCAGTAAGAGAC and AGAGTCCCCGGGTCAGACCAATGACTTTAGAAAACGCCCAGCCCCGTCTCTTACTGTGC. The amplified product was digested with EcoRI and SmaI and subcloned into CD3a cut with EcoRI and SmaI. Finally, this construct was linearized with EcoRI and ligated to an EcoRI fragment from β3containing its extracellular and transmembrane sequences. All constructs were identified by restriction digestion, purified by CsCl centrifugation, and verified by DNA sequencing before transfection. The activation index was defined as: 100 × (M - MR/ MA- MAR), where M = median fluorescence intensity of PAC1 binding, MR= median fluorescence intensity of PAC1 binding in the presence of Ro43-5054, MA= median fluorescence intensity of PAC1 binding in the presence of anti-LIBS6, and MAR= median fluorescence intensity of PAC1 binding in the presence of anti-LIBS6 and Ro43-5054. To identify residues in β cytoplasmic domains that are involved in the regulation of integrin affinity states, we have generated point mutations in these sequences and coexpressed these variants in CHO cells with αIIbchimeras. These α subunit chimeras consist of the extracellular and transmembrane domains of αIIbjoined to the cytoplasmic sequences of α5, α6A, or α6B. In contrast to wild type αIIb, these α chimeras conferred an energy-dependent, constitutive high affinity state when coexpressed with constructs encoding the wild type β3or β1cytoplasmic domains (20O'Toole T.E. Katagiri Y. Faull R.J. Peter K. Tamura R. Quaranta V. Loftus J.C. Shattil S.J. Ginsberg M.H. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 124: 1047-1059Crossref PubMed Scopus (578) Google Scholar). Thus, the affinity state of the extracellular reporter group, αIIbβ3, was determined by the identity of its cytoplasmic sequences. Point mutations were first generated in the cytoplasmic sequences of β1(Fig. 1), a natural partner for the α5and α6cytoplasmic domains. Areas targeted included several hydroxylated residues which represent potential phosphorylation sites, the two NP XY internalization motifs, and residues in the putative α-actinin binding site. Many of these residues have also been implicated in the recruitment of β1to focal adhesions (28Reszka A.A. Yokichi Y. Horwitz A.F. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 117: 1321-1330Crossref PubMed Scopus (240) Google Scholar). These variant cytoplasmic sequences were first joined to the extracellular and transmembrane domains of β3generating β subunit chimeras. To determine if cytoplasmic mutations affected integrin expression, cells cotransfected with these β chimeras and αIIbα5(a chimera consisting of extracellular and transmembrane αIIbjoined to cytoplasmic α5) were analyzed for surface expression by flow cytometry. Constructs encoding the wild type and variant forms of the β1cytoplasmic domain demonstrated comparable levels of surface expression (Fig. 2, panels A, D, and G) when stained with an anti-αIIbβ3-specific monoclonal antibody. Indeed, all of the β1variants utilized in this study were well expressed. In addition, no differences between wild type or mutant β1expression were observed when cotransfection was with the α6A or α6B chimeras. Heterodimer formation and surface expression of β1variants was also confirmed by the immunoprecipitation of iodinated transfectants (data not shown). Thus, the β1point mutations we have examined do not disrupt normal subunit association or cell surface expression.FIG. 2Representative FACS histograms. Only those cells positive for surface expression (denoted by M1 in Fig. 2) were gated and analyzed for PAC1 binding. Like cells transfected with wild type β1(panel B), those expressing the Y788F variant bound PAC1 constitutively (panel H). Binding was specific since it could be blocked with a ligand-mimetic compound, Ro43-5054. In contrast, cells transfected with the Y788A variant failed to bind PAC1 (panel E). Binding in the latter case was observed only in the presence of an activating antibody, anti-LIBS 6. To numerically express PAC1 binding and affinity state, we have determined an activation index (AI) for each α,β combination as described under “Materials and Methods.” The AI values were determined for each of the β1tail variants when cotransfected with the αIIbα6Bchimera and compared to the wild type sequence (Fig. 3 A). When analyzed in this way, the group of β1variants fell into three functional categories: those that conferred near wild type levels (70-100%) of PAC1 binding (Y788F, Y800F), those that result in reduced (10-70%) binding (F771L, E774V, S790M, S790D, T793V/T794V, N797I, Y800A), and those that abolished (<10%) binding (N785I, Y788A, YTRF). To determine if these effects were specific for the α6Bcytoplasmic tail, the β1variants were also transfected with other α constructs. Similar effects on PAC1 binding were observed when coexpression was with αIIbchimeras containing the cytoplasmic sequences from the α5(Fig. 3 B) and α6A(data not shown) subunits. These results suggest that mutations at several sites within the β1cytoplasmic domain reduce energy-dependent ligand binding. The β1and β3cytoplasmic domains are approximately 60% identical and contain conservative amino acid substitutions at several other positions. This high degree of conservation suggests the possibility that analogous regions in both tails have functional importance. To look at this possibility, we have generated point mutations in the β3tail at sites corresponding to those residues in β1which affect its binding function (Fig. 1). Like those β1point mutations, cytoplasmic variants of β3do not disrupt normal patterns of α,β subunit association or cell surface expression (data not shown). With respect to functional properties, transfectants expressing a β3cytoplasmic truncation (Δ724) or the F727A/F730L/E733V, Y747A, and S752P, variants demonstrate a greatly reduced (<10%) ability to bind PAC1 when coexpressed with the αIIbα6Bchimera (Fig. 4 A). Although still reduced relative to wild type β3, the Y759A and S752A variants exhibit a somewhat greater AI. Similar effects on PAC1 binding were observed when these β3variants were coexpressed with the α5(Fig. 4 B) or α6A (data not shown) chimeras. Thus analogous residues in the β1and β3tails affect ligand binding affinity. Finally, we have generated a construct (β3B) encoding an alternately spliced form of the β3cytoplasmic domain (33van Kuppevelt T. Languino L.R. Gailit J.O. Suzuki S. Rouslahti E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 5415-5418Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). This variant eliminates 8 of 10 hydroxylated residues and the NP XY motifs in this tail. While cotransfection with the β3B construct does result in surface expression (panel A), PAC1 binding was only observed in cells stimulated with anti-LIBS6 (panel C).View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) The results described above: 1) identify a distinct set of β cytoplasmic residues required for inside-out signaling (Fig. 6), 2) define a functional role for the NP XY motif in this is process, 3) argue against the hypothesis that the phosphorylation of integrin tails is required, and 4) suggest cytoplasmic splice variants are not responsive to normal inside-out signaling mechansims. The most significant reductions in constitutive PAC1 binding were achieved by substitutions of the β1cytoplasmic residues Asn785 and Tyr788. These residues encompass an NPIY sequence of this domain, a conserved motif (NP XY) found in many β subunit cytoplasmic domains. Indeed, the β1(34Argraves S.W. Suzuki S. Arai H. Thompson K. Pierschbacher M.D. Rouslahti E. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 1183-1190Crossref PubMed Scopus (386) Google Scholar), β2(35Kishimoto T.K. O'Connor K. Lee A. Roberts T.M. Springer T.A. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 108: 703-712Google Scholar), β3(36Zimrin A.B. Eisman R. Vilaire G. Schwartz E. Bennett J.S. Poncz M. J. Clin. Invest. 1988; 81: 1470-1475Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar), β5(37McLean J.W. Vestal D.J. Cheresh D.A. Bodary S.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 17126-17131Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), β6(38Sheppard D. Rozzo C. Starr L. Quaranta V. Erle D.J. Pytela R. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 11502-11506Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and β7(39Erle D.J. Ruegg C. Sheppard D. Pytela R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 11009-11016Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) cytoplasmic sequences typically contain one of these motifs within 30 residues of the transmembrane domain (Fig. 6). In addition, the β1and β2tails also have a more distal NP XY/F sequence, while other β subunits contain a distal N XXY/F motif. The NP XY motif has been identified in the cytoplasmic sequences of several cell surface receptors (10Chen W.-J. Goldstein J.L. Brown M.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 3116-3123Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). It functions as an internalization sequence for the LDL receptor (10Chen W.-J. Goldstein J.L. Brown M.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 3116-3123Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and is essential for cellular transformation by the polyomavirus middle T antigen (40Druker B.J. Sibert L. Roberts T.M. J. Virol. 1992; 66: 5770-5776Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Functional studies suggest that the Asn and Pro residues of this motif are invariant. Substitution of either in the LDL receptor results in a significant reduction of coated pit-mediated endocytosis (10Chen W.-J. Goldstein J.L. Brown M.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 3116-3123Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). While internalization was maintained when the terminal Tyr of this motif was substituted with another aromatic residue (Phe, Trp), substitution with a non-aromatic residue resulted in decreased LDL receptor internalization (41Davis C.G. van Driel I.R. Russell D.W. Brown M.S. Goldstein J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 4075-4082Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). These functional studies are similar to ours which demonstrated that substitution of Asn785 completely abolished PAC1 binding. Furthermore, we have observed a complete loss of PAC1 binding with the Y788A substitution but near wild type levels of binding with the more conservative Y788F variant. As predicted from these observations, we have determined that a β3cytoplasmic splice variant lacking the NP XY sequence is incapable of supporting constitutive PAC1 binding. Splice variants of β1lacking its NP XY motifs would also be predicted to be unresponsive to inside-out signaling mechanisms. A second internalization motif, originally identified in the transferrin receptor, is Y XRF (42Collawn J.F. Stangel M. Kuhn L.A. Esekogwu V. Jing S. Trowbridge I.S. Tainer J.A. Cell. 1990; 63: 1061-1072Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (392) Google Scholar). Molecular modeling (42Collawn J.F. Stangel M. Kuhn L.A. Esekogwu V. Jing S. Trowbridge I.S. Tainer J.A. Cell. 1990; 63: 1061-1072Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (392) Google Scholar) and NMR analysis of wild type peptides (43Bansal A. Gierasch L.M. Cell. 1991; 67: 1195-1201Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar) suggest that both NP XY and YTRF form a reverse turn conformation. This conformation is hypothesized to present a recognition domain to adaptins in clathrin-coated pits thereby mediating uptake (43Bansal A. Gierasch L.M. Cell. 1991; 67: 1195-1201Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). Interestingly, peptides derived from receptors defective in endocytosis do not form the turn conformation. In our studies, the substitution of NPIY for YTRF in the β1tail completely abolished PAC1 binding. Since this substitution might not disrupt overall structure, the abolition of PAC1 binding is probably related to the loss of specific NPIY residues. It is conceivable that the NP XY motif could represent a recognition site for regulatory, intracellular moieties. Interestingly peptides spanning this region also inhibit talin-integrin interactions in vitro (44Tapley P. Horwitz A. Buck C. Duggan K. Rohrschneider L. Oncogene. 1989; 4: 325-333PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, our results suggest a novel role for the membrane-proximal NP XY motif in the regulation of ligand binding. Meanwhile, the role of the NP XY motif in integrin internalization is ambiguous. Expression of a β2truncation that lacks its two NP XF motifs or an F-A substitution variant in the membrane-proximal NP XF both result in a loss of internalization (45Rabb H. Michishita M. Sharma C.P. Brown D. Arnaout M.A. J. Immunol. 1993; 151: 990-1002PubMed Google Scholar). In contrast, substitution of the tyrosines for serines in the two NP XY motifs of β1had no effect on α5β1internalization (46Vignoud L. Usson Y. Balzac F. Tarone G. Block M.R. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1994; 199: 603-611Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Finally, the NP XY motifs of β3do not mediate internalization of αIIbβ3. 2J. Ylanne, J. Huuskonen, T. E. O'Toole, M. H. Ginsberg, I. Virtanen, and C. G. Gahmberg, manuscript in preparation. In contrast, amino acid substitutions within the distal NP XY motif of β1(N797I, Y800A, Y800F) had a lesser effect on receptor affinity. Similarly, a mutation in β3(Y759A) analogous to β1Y800A shows a reduced but variable ability to bind PAC1. Thus these residues do not seem to be nearly as crucial for the maintenance of high affinity binding as those in the first NP XY. Consistent with these results, this motif is not nearly as well conserved amongst β cytoplasmic sequences. As noted above, only β1and β2possess an exact distal NP XY/F sequence. While these sequences may play a minor role in the regulation of binding affinity, this motif in β2is required for cellular adhesion. Substitution of phenylalanine in the distal NP XF of this subunit abolished αLβ2-intracellular adhesion molecule 1 (ICAM-1) interactions (5Hibbs M.L. Jakes S. Stacker S.A. Wallace R.W. Springer T.A. J. Exp. Med. 1991; 174: 1227-1238Crossref PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar). The phosphorylation of integrin tails has been proposed to play a role in affinity modulation. In our studies, two variants which completely block PAC1 binding, β3S752P and β1Y788A, also represent potential phosphorylation sites. However, more conservative, yet phosphorylation-defective, substitutions at these residues (S752A and Y788F) results in greater or near wild type levels of PAC1 binding (Figs. 3 and 4). Thus the abolition of binding by S752P and Y788A is due to an effect other than on phosphorylation. Similarly, other β1(S790M, S790D, T793V/T794V, Y800A) and β3(Y747A, Y759A) variants, which eliminate potential phosphorylation sites, retain measurable levels of PAC1 binding. These results argue strongly against a role of phosphorylation in the enhancement of binding affinity and are consistent with others that discount a role for phosphorylation in promoting cellular adhesion (5Hibbs M.L. Jakes S. Stacker S.A. Wallace R.W. Springer T.A. J. Exp. Med. 1991; 174: 1227-1238Crossref PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar, 14Shaw L.M. Mercurio A.M. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 123: 1017-1025Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 47Hogervorst F. Kuikman I. Noteboom E. Sonnenberg A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 18427-18430Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 48Delwel G.O. Hogervorst F. Kuikman I. Paulsson M. Timp R Sonnenberg A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25865-25875Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). It is apparent that mutations at several sites within the β tail reduced or abolished PAC1 binding. In addition to those variants discussed above, β1(F771L, E774V) and β3(F727A/F730L/E733V) substitutions within the putative α-actinin binding site (7Otey C.A. Vasquez G.B. Burridge K. Erickson B.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 21193-21197Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) also reduced constitutive PAC1 binding. One explanation for these observations is that the dynamic regulation of ligand binding does involve many sites in the β tail. Alternatively, β tail folding and conformation may be extremely sensitive to amino acid substitution and it is these conformational changes which disrupt normal signaling pathways. It is also noteworthy that similar qualitative effects on PAC1 binding were observed whether the β1or β3point mutations were coexpressed with chimeras containing the α5, α6Aor α6Btails. It is possible that high affinity binding specified by these different α tails might involve a single regulatory pathway and thus the same β cytoplasmic sequence elements. Alternatively, each integrin may be independently regulated yet utilize the same β sequence elements. In this latter case integrin specific regulation would be mediated by sequences in the α chain. Distinguishing between these possibilities and identifying the mechanisms of cell-specific affinity modulation awaits further study. In summary, we have defined a subset of β cytoplasmic residues required for inside-out signaling. Substitutions within a membrane-proximal NP XY motif were the most effective in the abolition of binding, suggesting a novel function for this sequence. Defining the interaction of intracellular elements with these sequences will contribute to an understanding of the mechanisms of affinity modulation. We thank Mark Ginsberg for suggestions and critical review of the manuscript.

Water-soluble UV-A/B-absorbing pigments are secreted by cells of the cosmopolitan terrestrial cyanobacterium Nostoc commune. The pigments constitute a complex mixture of monomers with molecular masses of up to 1801 Da. Two different chromophores with absorption maxima at 312 and 335 nm are linked to different amino acids and to oligosaccharides consisting of galactose, glucose, xylose, glucuronic acid, and glucosamine. The 335 nm chromophore is a 1,3-diaminocyclohexen derivative, while the chromophore with an absorption maximum at 312 nm is most likely a 3-aminocyclohexen-1-one derivative. These UV-inducible substances are the first mycosporines to be described covalently linked to oligosaccharides. The pigments are located in the extracellular glycan sheath of Nostoc colonies, where they form complexes of extremely high molecular mass that are attached noncovalently to the glycan sheath. Pigments occur in concentrations that permit the cells to attenuate a significant part of incident UV-B radiation. Water-soluble UV-A/B-absorbing pigments are secreted by cells of the cosmopolitan terrestrial cyanobacterium Nostoc commune. The pigments constitute a complex mixture of monomers with molecular masses of up to 1801 Da. Two different chromophores with absorption maxima at 312 and 335 nm are linked to different amino acids and to oligosaccharides consisting of galactose, glucose, xylose, glucuronic acid, and glucosamine. The 335 nm chromophore is a 1,3-diaminocyclohexen derivative, while the chromophore with an absorption maximum at 312 nm is most likely a 3-aminocyclohexen-1-one derivative. These UV-inducible substances are the first mycosporines to be described covalently linked to oligosaccharides. The pigments are located in the extracellular glycan sheath of Nostoc colonies, where they form complexes of extremely high molecular mass that are attached noncovalently to the glycan sheath. Pigments occur in concentrations that permit the cells to attenuate a significant part of incident UV-B radiation. Microorganisms possess a variety of UV-protecting mechanisms, some of which (e.g. the SOS response) have been elucidated in great detail. Additionally, cells are equipped with radical quenchers and antioxidants that provide protection by scavenging harmful radicals or oxygen species. A variety of cells, including cyanobacteria, produce UV-absorbing substances that are thought to serve as sunscreen molecules (Garcia-Pichel and Castenholz, 1993Garcia-Pichel F. Castenholz R.W. Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 1993; 59: 163-169Crossref PubMed Google Scholar; Karentz et al., 1991Karentz D. McEuen F.S. Land M.C. Dunlap W.C. Mar. Biol. (Berl.). 1991; 108: 157-166Crossref Scopus (419) Google Scholar; Post and Larkum, 1993Post A. Larkum A.W.D. Aquat. Bot. 1993; 45: 231-243Crossref Scopus (79) Google Scholar; Scherer et al., 1988Scherer S. Chen T.W. Böger P. Plant Physiol. 1988; 88: 1055-1057Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The occurrence of colorless UV-B-absorbing substances in cyanobacteria has been known for at least 25 years (Shibata, 1969Shibata K. Plant Cell Physiol. 1969; 10: 325-335Google Scholar). More recently, the induction of such compounds by UV-B was demonstrated (Garcia-Pichel et al., 1993Garcia-Pichel F. Wingard C.E. Castenholz R.W. Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 1993; 59: 170-176Crossref PubMed Google Scholar; Scherer et al., 1988Scherer S. Chen T.W. Böger P. Plant Physiol. 1988; 88: 1055-1057Crossref PubMed Google Scholar. However, the structure of these cyanobacterial secondary products is not known. The terrestrial cyanobacterium Nostoc commune is well adapted to live under extraordinary environmental conditions. Besides withstanding extreme water stress (for review, see Potts, 1994Potts M. Microbiol. Rev. 1994; 58: 755-805Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), this organism can tolerate high levels of UV radiation. In this paper, the structure of a chromophore of a UV-B-absorbing pigment that is synthesized upon UV radiation is reported. 750-g fresh, wet colonies of N. commune var. Vaucher, collected after rains in South Germany during Spring 1992, were extracted in 2.5 liters of methanol:water (3:7) for 1.5 h at 40°C. After filtration and reduction of the volume to 0.1, the green filtrate was further purified by protein precipitation with chloroform. Additional proteins were removed by DE52 anion-exchange chromatography, and the flow-through fraction was eluted 2-fold from a gel exclusion chromatography column (Sephadex G-25; Pharmacia, Uppsala, Sweden). After concentration by freeze-drying, fractions were separated by reversed-phase HPLC 1The abbreviations used are:HPLChigh pressure liquid chromatographyPD-MSplasma desorption-mass spectrometryE312chromophore absorbing at 312 nmE335chromophore absorbing at 335 nm. (5-μm RP-18 column, 125 × 4 mm; E. Merck AG, Darmstadt, Germany) with a linear gradient from 100% water to 5% acetonitrile in water (v/v) in 30 min.
