J. 1994; 304: 313-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar) or by direct intracellular perfusion of InsP3(6Thorn P. Lawrie A.M. Smith P.M. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. Cell. 1993; 74: 661-668Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (430) Google Scholar, 8Kasai H. Li Y.X. Miyashita Y. Cell. 1993; 74: 669-677Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (317) Google Scholar). We have shown recently that this polarization is not due to a difference in the kinetic properties of the Ca2+release process in the two regions of the cell (7Toescu E.C. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. Biochem. J. 1994; 304: 313-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar). An important functional mechanism underlying this polarization is the heterogeneity in the sensitivity of the intracellular Ca2+pools to the actions of the Ca2+releasing agents (6Thorn P. Lawrie A.M. Smith P.M. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. Cell. 1993; 74: 661-668Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (430) Google Scholar, 7Toescu E.C. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. Biochem. J. 1994; 304: 313-316Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar, 8Kasai H. Li Y.X. Miyashita Y. Cell. 1993; 74: 669-677Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (317) Google Scholar, 9Lawrie A.M. Toescu E.C. Gallacher D.V. Cell Calcium. 1993; 14: 698-710Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 10van de Putt F.H.M.M. De Pont J.J.H.H.M. Willems P.H.G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 12438-12443Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, we reported previously that the intracellular Ca2+buffers have also an important role in the regulation of the agonist-evoked Ca2+signals (11Petersen C.C.H. Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 527-533Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar, 12Toescu E.C. Lawrie A.M. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 18654-18658Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In a more general definition, these Ca2+buffers include not only the cytosolic Ca2+-binding proteins, already implicated in a model of “dynamic decoding” (13Kasai H. Neurosci. Res. 1993; 16: 1-7Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar), but also the systems involved in the removal of Ca2+from the cytosol. Among the latter, the PM Ca2+ATPase is an established contender, shown to extrude a substantial amount of Ca2+following the agonist-evoked Ca2+signals (14Tepikin A.V. Voronina S.G. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3569-3572Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate inositol 1,3,4,5-tetrakiphosphate plasma membrane. The initial release of Ca2+is followed by a second phase of the Ca2+response, sensitive to the manipulation of extracellular Ca2+. In the absence of extracellular Ca2+maximal agonist stimulation still evokes an increase of [Ca2+]i, but only transient, due to the activation of the Ca2+extrusion mechanisms, represented in pancreatic acinar cells mainly by the PM Ca2+ATPase (14Tepikin A.V. Voronina S.G. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3569-3572Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Muallem S. Annu. Rev. Physiol. 1989; 51: 83-105Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). In the presence of extracellular Ca2+, the extrusion of Ca2+is balanced by an entry of Ca2+from the external medium, the two processes resulting in a maintained, steady-state plateau of increased [Ca2+]i. Several lines of evidence, brought together into the model of capacitative Ca2+entry (16Putney Jr., J.W. Cell Calcium. 1990; 11: 611-624Crossref PubMed Scopus (1264) Google Scholar, 17Putney Jr., J.W. Bird G.S.J. Endocr. Rev. 1993; 14: 610-631Crossref PubMed Scopus (486) Google Scholar), point to the fact that the activation of the Ca2+entry pathway is a consequence of the depletion of the intracellular Ca2+pools. Regarding the nature of this Ca2+pathway, several patch clamp studies (18Hoth M. Penner R. Nature. 1992; 355: 353-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (1495) Google Scholar, 19Fasolato C. Hoth M. Penner R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 20737-20740Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) identified a Ca2+-release-activated Ca2+current (ICRAC). What is still very much a matter of debate is the question of how the depletion of the stores is transduced into the activation of the Ca2+entry channel and numerous hypotheses have been proposed to account for this process. These include models of “mechanical coupling” involving direct interactions between the InsP3-sensitive Ca2+release channel/receptor and the Ca2+entry pathway mediated through an InsP4receptor (20Irvine R.F. FASEB J. 1992; 6: 3085-3091Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar) or through the cytoskeleton (17Putney Jr., J.W. Bird G.S.J. Endocr. Rev. 1993; 14: 610-631Crossref PubMed Scopus (486) Google Scholar). Other “metabolic coupling” models propose that the activation of the Ca2+entry pathway is the result of either (a) the stimulation of certain metabolic pathways, such as the cytochrome P450 (21Alvarez J. Montero M. Garcia-Sancho J. FASEB J. 1992; 6: 786-792Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar) or the NO/cGMP (22Xu X. Star R.A. Tortorici G. Muallem S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 12645-12653Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), (b) the release of a diffusible messenger (the “Ca2+influx factor” (23Randriamampita C. Tsien R.Y. Nature. 1993; 364: 809-814Crossref PubMed Scopus (789) Google Scholar)), or (c) the activation of small GTP-binding proteins (19Fasolato C. Hoth M. Penner R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 20737-20740Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Bird G.S. Putney J.W.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 268: 21486-21488Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar) or tyrosine kinase(s) (25Lee K.-M. Toscas K. Villereal M.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 9945-9948Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The analysis is further complicated by the fact that in some cell types, such as the hepatocytes, agonist stimulation activates several Ca2+entry pathways (26Llopis J. Kass G.E.N. Gahm A. Orrenius S. Biochem. J. 1992; 284: 243-247Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar, 27Kass G.E.N. Webb D.-L. Chow S.C. Llopis J. Berggren P.-O. Biochem. J. 1994; 302: 5-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). An important parameter which could help in differentiating between these various proposals is that of the temporal relationship between the depletion of the Ca2+pools and the activation of the Ca2+entry pathway. In the present study digital Ca2+imaging technologies were used to investigate the spatial and temporal aspects of the activation of the plasma membrane Ca2+transport systems following the maximal stimulation of the pancreatic acinar cells by an InsP3-mobilizing agonist. The main conclusions of this study are that (a) the temporal activation of the Ca2+extrusion system is very different from that of the Ca2+entry pathway, (b) the activation of the Ca2+entry pathway is significantly delayed in respect to the mobilization of Ca2+from the intracellular pools, and (c) the PM Ca2+pump display different patterns of activity in different regions of the cell, which could be an important mechanism in the polarization of the Ca2+signal. Individual cells and small clusters of acinar cells were obtained from isolated mouse pancreata by enzymatic dispersion in a water bath at 37°C as described previously (4Toescu E.C. Lawrie A.M. Petersen O.H. Gallacher D.V. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 1623-1629Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). Briefly, the intact glands were injected with a collagenase solution (200 units/ml, Worthington), incubated for 7-15 min, and finally manually agitated to yield the isolated cell preparation. Throughout the preparation procedure and subsequently in some experiments, a buffer solution (“control” solution) containing (m M): NaCl 140, KCl 4.7, CaCl21.1, MgCl21.1, glucose 10, and HEPES 10 (pH 7.2 adjusted with NaOH) with an osmolality of 295 mOsm/liter was used. For some experiments a “0 Ca” solution was used which consisted of a nominally Ca2+-free control solution to which 0.5 m M EGTA was added. To inhibit all the plasma membrane Ca2+transport systems (28Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. Pfluegers Arch. 1994; 444: 325-331Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar), 1 m M La3+was added to the control solution (“lanthanum” solution). Cells were loaded with 1 μM fura-2-AM for 30 min at room temperature, washed twice, and used within 3-4 h. During experiments, the cells, placed on a glass coverslip attached to an open perfusion chamber, were continuously perifused from a gravity-fed perifusion system. The images were captured using a Nikon Diaphot inverted microscope, an intensified charge coupled device camera (Photonic Science Inc.) and recorded on a MagiCal station (Applied Imaging, UK). Other details of the Ca2+imaging were described previously (9Lawrie A.M. Toescu E.C. Gallacher D.V. Cell Calcium. 1993; 14: 698-710Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). The fluorescence signals were captured, at video-frame rate (0.16-s intervals between two true ratio images) with a 20× magnification objective. In each field, comprising several cells, those cells responding to agonist were analyzed by calculating the mean [Ca2+]ivalue within areas defined with a light-sensitive pen on a bright field image showing the morphology of cells. The areas used for these measurements were of a similar size to those used by us previously (4Toescu E.C. Lawrie A.M. Petersen O.H. Gallacher D.V. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 1623-1629Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar, 9Lawrie A.M. Toescu E.C. Gallacher D.V. Cell Calcium. 1993; 14: 698-710Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). Due to biological variability and to the inherently variable geometry of our perifusion method, the lag time between the start of agonist application and the initiation of Ca2+response varied from one experiment to another. To compare agonist-evoked Ca2+signals in different experiments we have chosen to normalize the Ca2+signal to the first time point of the [Ca2+]iincrease (defined as the first point of increase of [Ca2+]iwhich is followed by two consecutive higher values of [Ca2+]i). Fura-2 fluorescence was calibrated using the cells loaded in the normal way and perfused subsequently either with 10 m M EGTA or with 10 m M Ca2+, in the presence of 2 m M ionomycin. The dissociation constant for fura 2 (Kd) used for the calculation of the Ca2+values was 224 n M. Chemicals were purchased from Merck-BDH (UK) and Sigma (UK) except fura-2 which was obtained from Novo-Calbiochem (UK). Fig. 1A depicts schematically the major Ca2+transport processes which participate in establishing the value of [Ca2+]iduring the agonist-evoked, InsP3-mediated Ca2+signaling in nonexcitable cells. Clearly, in such studies which measure the resultant [Ca2+]i, the direct and separate assessment of the participation of each process to the overall [Ca2+]ivalue is not possible. Nevertheless, by using certain experimental conditions and by performing simple algebraic additions as shown in Fig. 1B, the relative participation of the plasma membrane Ca2+transport systems can be ascertained. In the presence of maximal agonist stimulation and for the short duration (10 s) of these experiments, the InsP3-activated Ca2+release channel (Fig. 1 A, process 1) is assumed to be continuously activated. In the absence of extracellular Ca2+(Fig. 1 B, trace C), the participation of the capacitative Ca2+entry pathway (Fig. 1 A, process 2) is eliminated. We have shown recently (28Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. Pfluegers Arch. 1994; 444: 325-331Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar) that 1 m M La3+effectively seals the cell with respect to extracellular Ca2+, blocking both the entry and the extrusion of Ca2+(Fig. 1 A, processes 2 and 3, respectively) and results in an increased Ca2+signal (28Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. Pfluegers Arch. 1994; 444: 325-331Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar) (Fig. 1 C). As shown in Fig. 1 B, the difference between traces obtained in the presence of La3+(trace A) and those obtained in the absence of extracellular Ca2+(trace C) are due only to the activity of the plasma membrane Ca2+ATPase. Similarly, subtraction of traces obtained in the absence of extracellular Ca2+from traces obtained in control conditions (trace B) will provide information about the behavior of the Ca2+entry pathway. Fig. 1 C shows the actual experimental (mean) values, measured across the whole cell and normalized for the first value of increased [Ca2+]ias detailed under “Materials and Methods.” The participation of the plasma membrane Ca2+transport system was assessed for each time point, as the difference between the [Ca2+]imeasured in the presence of extracellular La3+(1 m M) and in the absence of extracellular Ca2+(Fig. 1 B). In agreement with our previous suggestion (28Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. Pfluegers Arch. 1994; 444: 325-331Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar), it appears that this Ca2+transport system is activated very early during maximal agonist stimulation. Within 0.5 s the difference in [Ca2+]idue to the PM Ca2+ATPase is manifest, and it reaches a maximal level in less than 2 s (Fig. 2 A), by which time it accounts for a difference of 350 n M Ca2+. Throughout the rest of the stimulation the Ca2+pump remains active. An important property of this transport system is illustrated in Fig. 2 B which shows the relationship between the apparent extrusion rate, calculated from data shown in Fig. 2 A as the difference (d) in [Ca2+]ivalues per unit of time (d[Ca2+]i/ dt), and the values of [Ca2+]i. The noteworthy feature of this relationship is its steepness: at values of [Ca2+]iover 200 n M, even small changes in the value of [Ca2+]ievoke big increases in the apparent rate of extrusion. At [Ca2+]ivalues around 600 n M, the apparent rate is maximal (370 n M Ca2+/s). Further increases of [Ca2+]ido not determine any significant additional activation. The activation of the Ca2+entry pathway can be derived from the comparison between control experiments and those performed in the absence of extracellular Ca2+(see Fig. 1 B). It is apparent from Fig. 1 C that the values of [Ca2+]imeasured in the first seconds after the beginning of [Ca2+]iincrease are, in pancreatic acinar cells, little affected by the absence of extracellular Ca2+, and the two curves are almost superimposable. As shown in Fig. 3 A the participation of the Ca2+entry is significantly delayed, requiring more than 6 s for its activation. This time scale is to be contrasted with the time course of Ca2+release from the intracellular Ca2+pools following agonist stimulation (Fig. 3 B). Since La3+inhibits all Ca2+transport across the plasma membrane (28Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. Pfluegers Arch. 1994; 444: 325-331Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar, 36Kwan C.-Y. Takemura H. Obie J.F. Thastrup O. Putney J.W.J. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: C1006-C1015Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), the measured values of [Ca2+]iin its presence reflect only the release from the intracellular Ca2+pools. The trace plotted in Fig. 3 B shows that, by 3 s, the [Ca2+]ireached a steady-state level, maintained afterward. This steady-state level is the result of the maximal efflux of Ca2+from the intracellular stores through the Ca2+release channels balanced by the reuptake into the stores through the endoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ATPase. As such, it represents a level of maximal “effective” depletion of the pools, which is thus completed by 3 s after the initiation of the Ca2+release and precedes by 3-4 s the activation of the Ca2+entry pathway. The use of Ca2+imaging allows the analysis of changes in [Ca2+]iin different regions of the cell. In many exocrine cells, the Ca2+signal is initially localized to the lumenal pole from where, 0.3-0.5 s later, it spreads toward the basolateral pole. Using a similar methodology, we investigated the pattern of activation and the apparent kinetic properties of the PM Ca2+transport in different regions of the pancreatic acinar cells. Fig. 4A shows the mean increases in [Ca2+]irecorded during the agonist-evoked Ca2+signal in the lumenal pole of pancreatic acinar cells in the presence of La3+or absence of extracellular Ca2+, respectively. As in previous figures the data were normalized to the first increase in [Ca2+]i. From these results, the time course of the activation of the PM Ca2+extrusion system at the lumenal pole was calculated and shown in Fig. 4B. In this figure the extrusion activity is plotted together with the “reference” [Ca2+]itrace (i.e. that recorded in the absence of extracellular Ca2, when the PM Ca2+ATPase is active). The increase of [Ca2+]irapidly activates the extrusion system, and its activity is maximal in less than 2 s, by which time it accounts for a difference of about 200 n M Ca2+. It can also be seen from Fig. 4 B that the lumenal PM Ca2+ATPase maintains the same level of activity despite further increases of [Ca2+]i. Using the same procedure, the activity of the PM Ca2+ATPase in the basal pole of the cells was assessed. These values are plotted in Fig. 4 C together with the corresponding reference [Ca2+]itrace in that region of the cell. To allow a direct comparison of the activation curves between the two regions, the initial time point in this graph is represented by the first increase of [Ca2+]i not in this region, but in the lumenal pole. In the present set of data, as in previously published reports (2Kasai H. Augustine G.J. Nature. 1990; 348: 735-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (314) Google Scholar, 4Toescu E.C. Lawrie A.M. Petersen O.H. Gallacher D.V. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 1623-1629Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar, 6Thorn P. Lawrie A.M. Smith P.M. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. Cell. 1993; 74: 661-668Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (430) Google Scholar, 8Kasai H. Li Y.X. Miyashita Y. Cell. 1993; 74: 669-677Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (317) Google Scholar), the increase of [Ca2+]iin the lumenal pole precedes that in the basal pole by 0.3-0.4 s. In striking contrast to the activity of the Ca2+extrusion system in the lumenal pole (Fig. 4 B), in the basal pole of the pancreatic acinar cells the activity of the pump, after being maximally stimulated within 1.5 s, is inhibited despite further increases of [Ca2+]i. A direct comparison of the time course of the activation of the Ca2+extrusion systems in the two regions of the cell is presented in Fig. 5A which illustrates better the important differences between these two activities. The apparent rate of Ca2+extrusion activation in the basal pole of the cell is almost twice as great as that seen in the lumenal pole. This increased rate of activity is associated also with a greater maximal activity. Finally, whereas the apparent activity of the PM Ca2+extrusion system in the lumenal pole remains largely constant, in the basal pole it decreases immediately following its peak of activation. As seen in Fig. 4 B, this decrease of Ca2+extrusion activity is associated with further increases in [Ca2+]i. The relationship between Ca2+extrusion and [Ca2+]ifor the two regions of the cell is presented in Fig. 5 B. Both the lumenal and the basal extrusion systems are activated by an increase of [Ca2+]i, but the activation in the basal pole is much more sensitive to changes in [Ca2+]i. Thus, for increases of 100 n M Ca2+above the resting [Ca2+]ivalue, the extrusion in the lumenal pole will account for a Ca2+difference of only 40 n M Ca2+, whereas in the basal pole the difference is 150 n M Ca2+. In both regions the extrusion systems reach a maximum activity at [Ca2+]iaround 0.7 μM, but the maximum value at the basal pole is higher than that in the lumenal pole. As discussed before, at higher values of [Ca2+]ithe extrusion in the two regions behave differently in respect to [Ca2+]i: whereas in the lumenal region the activity remains constant, in the basal pole further increases of [Ca2+]iare associated with a decrease of extrusion, indicating an inhibitory effect of [Ca2+]i. Next, the activation of the Ca2+entry pathway was analyzed in a similar manner. Fig. 6 A shows the mean [Ca2+]itraces recorded in the lumenal pole in control conditions and in the absence of extracellular Ca2+. From these traces the time course of Ca2+entry activation was calculated and is shown in Fig. 6B (filled squares). Fig. 6 B also shows that, in contrast to the activity of the PM Ca2+extrusion system, there are no significant differences in the activation of the PM Ca2+entry pathway between the lumenal and basal poles of the pancreatic acinar cells. Two main conclusions emerge from the present results. The first one is that, following maximal agonist stimulation, the time course of activation of the two major PM Ca2+transport systems, i.e. the extrusion and the entry pathway, is significantly different, with the Ca2+entry pathway becoming active more than 5 s after the initiation of the Ca2+release from the intracellular Ca2+pools. Second, it is shown that the polarization of the Ca2+signal, reported previously for several cell types (2Kasai H. Augustine G.J. Nature. 1990; 348: 735-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (314) Google Scholar, 3Rooney T.A. Sass E. Thomas A.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10792-10796Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 4Toescu E.C. Lawrie A.M. Petersen O.H. Gallacher D.V. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 1623-1629Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar, 5Theler J.M. Mollard P. Guerineau N. Vacher P. Pralong W.F. Schlegel W. Wolheim C.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 18110-18117Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 29Elliot A.C. Cairns S.P. Allen D.G. Pfluegers Arch. 1992; 422: 245-252Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar), is associated with significant differences in the activity of the PM Ca2+extrusion system in two functionally distinct regions of the pancreatic acinar cells, the lumenal and the basal pole. The question of the participation of the plasma membrane Ca2+transport systems during the agonist-evoked Ca2+signal is still debated. The entry of Ca2+into cells along a strong electrochemical gradient is regulated by a variety of mechanisms (30Tsien R.W. Tsien R.Y. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1990; 6: 715-716Crossref PubMed Scopus (1022) Google Scholar). In electrically nonexcitable cells a salient feature of this process is that the depletion of the intracellular Ca2+pools activates a Ca2+entry pathway (16Putney Jr., J.W. Cell Calcium. 1990; 11: 611-624Crossref PubMed Scopus (1264) Google Scholar). The molecular nature of this Ca2+entry pathway and, more importantly, the mechanisms which activate it are the subject of intensive research. In some cell types, the burst of [Ca2+]iincrease during threshold or maximal stimulation is preceded by a slow pacemaker elevation of [Ca2+]i(31Iino M. Yamazawa T. Miyashita Y. Endo M. Kasai H. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 5287-5291Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar, 32Friel D.D. Tsien R.W. Neuron. 1992; 8: 1109-1125Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar, 33Miyazaki S. Yuzaki M. Nakada K. Shirakawa H. Nakanishi S. Nakade S. Mikoshiba K. Science. 1992; 257: 251-255Crossref PubMed Scopus (449) Google Scholar). Recently, it has been proposed that an important component of this phase is the entry of external Ca2+(34Berridge M.J. Biochem. J. 1994; 302: 545-550Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). This view extends a previous model (1Berridge M.J. Nature. 1993; 361: 315-325Crossref PubMed Scopus (6188) Google Scholar, 35Goldbetter A. Dupont G. Berridge M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 1461-1465Crossref PubMed Scopus (548) Google Scholar) in which it is proposed that an influx of external Ca2+is an essential primer for the ensuing [Ca2+]iincrease. This primer Ca2+initially loads the intracellular pools and subsequently sensitize the Ca2+release process eventually determining the sudden release of Ca2+from the endoplasmic reticulum. Implicit in this model is the fact that the pools are initially depleted of Ca2+. The situation in the pancreatic acinar cells appears somewhat different. Stimulation of cells in the presence of lanthanum at a concentration which effectively seals these cells from the extracellular Ca2+(28Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. Pfluegers Arch. 1994; 444: 325-331Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar, 36Kwan C.-Y. Takemura H. Obie J.F. Thastrup O. Putney J.W.J. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: C1006-C1015Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) evokes an increase of [Ca2+]iwhich is more rapid and of higher amplitude than in the absence of extracellular Ca2+(Fig. 1) (28Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. Pfluegers Arch. 1994; 444: 325-331Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar) indicating that the InsP3-sensitive stores are fully Ca2+-loaded. In addition, treatment with thapsigargin evokes, even in the absence of extracellular Ca2+, increases of [Ca2+]i. Finally, as shown in Fig. 3, the activation of Ca2+entry appears a few seconds after the maximal release of Ca2+from the stores. This delayed activation has also been suggested previously, in experiments using short 0Ca2+pulses during the increase of [Ca2+]ifollowing thapsigargin exposure (28Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. Pfluegers Arch. 1994; 444: 325-331Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar). The delay in Fig. 3 indicates another important feature: the entry is not activated directly as a consequence of pool depletion. The length of this delay (3-5 s) exclude, at least for this cell type, a number activation mechanisms, including a direct receptor-regulated Ca2+channel (37Felder C. Poulter M.O. Wess J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 509-513Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar) or the participation of a plasma membrane, InsP3-activated Ca2+channel (38Kuno M. Gardner P. Nature. 1987; 326: 301-304Crossref PubMed Scopus (471) Google Scholar, 39Khan A.A. Steiner J.P. Kelin M.G. Schneider M.F. Snyder S.H. Science. 1992; 249: 1166-1168Google Scholar, 40Fadool D.A. Ache B.W. Neuron. 1992; 9: 907-918Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar), and suggests the existence of a metabolic step interposed between store depletion and Ca2+entry activation. The nature of this process is yet unclear. One proposal involves the cytochrome P450 (21Alvarez J. Montero M. Garcia-Sancho J. FASEB J. 1992; 6: 786-792Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar), but more recent evidence seem to argue strongly against it (e.g. see Ref. 41Koch B.D. Faurot G.F. Kopanitsa M.V. Swinney D.C. Biochem. J. 1994; 302: 187-190Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Other possibilities include the (paracrine) mediation by a Ca2+-influx factor (23Randriamampita C. Tsien R.Y. Nature. 1993; 364: 809-814Crossref PubMed Scopus (789) Google Scholar) or the participation of small G-proteins (19Fasolato C. Hoth M. Penner R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 20737-20740Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Bird G.S. Putney J.W.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 268: 21486-21488Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar). In pancreatic acinar cells, the main Ca2+extrusion system is represented by the PM Ca2+ATPase since the participation of the Na+/Ca2+exchanger is minimal (14Tepikin A.V. Voronina S.G. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3569-3572Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Muallem S. Annu. Rev. Physiol. 1989; 51: 83-105Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). The present data show that this system, which is extremely powerful (14Tepikin A.V. Voronina S.G. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3569-3572Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), is rapidly activated following agonist stimulation, in a manner dependent on [Ca2+]i(Fig. 2 B). An important feature of this dependence is its steepness: even small increases of [Ca2+]iabove the resting values induce significant increases in the pump activity. Analysis of the PM Ca2+extrusion in different regions of the cell revealed that the apparent activity of the pump is different. Pancreatic acinar cells, like many other cell types, display a polarization of the Ca2+signal (2Kasai H. Augustine G.J. Nature. 1990; 348: 735-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (314) Google Scholar, 4Toescu E.C. Lawrie A.M. Petersen O.H. Gallacher D.V. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 1623-1629Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). This polarization could be explained on the basis of differential sensitivity of intracellular Ca2+stores to the action of the Ca2+releasing agents (6Thorn P. Lawrie A.M. Smith P.M. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. Cell. 1993; 74: 661-668Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (430) Google Scholar, 8Kasai H. Li Y.X. Miyashita Y. Cell. 1993; 74: 669-677Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (317) Google Scholar, 10van de Putt F.H.M.M. De Pont J.J.H.H.M. Willems P.H.G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 12438-12443Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This hypothesis is supported by recent immunolocalization data showing a preferential localization of the InsP3receptor type 3 to the lumenal pole (42Nathanson M.H. Fallon M.B. Padfield P.J. Maranto A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 4693-4696Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). An alternative mechanism, not exclusive of the first, is the existence of a differential buffering in different regions of the cell. Intracellular addition of mobile, high capacity, low affinity Ca2+buffers induce significant changes in the pattern of Ca2+oscillations (11Petersen C.C.H. Toescu E.C. Petersen O.H. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 527-533Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). In situ cytosolic Ca2+buffers have been invoked in a model explaining the characteristics of the interspike period (43Petersen C.C.H. Petersen O.H. Berridge M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 22262-22264Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We have also proposed that the status of intracellular Ca2+buffers play an important role in determining the specific pattern of Ca2+oscillations independent of the nature of the agonist (12Toescu E.C. Lawrie A.M. Gallacher D.V. Petersen O.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 18654-18658Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In this context, the PM Ca2+extrusion system can be seen as an effective cytosolic Ca2+buffer. The different activities in the two poles of the pancreatic acinar cells might play an important role in the generation of the polarity of Ca2+signal. Thus, even with a homogenous release of Ca2+across the cytosol, the more rapid activation of the pump and its higher level of activity in the basal pole would explain the delay in the rise of [Ca2+]iat this pole. Recent molecular biology studies showed that the generic PM Ca2+ATPase is in fact a large multigene family (PMCA family) (44Carafoli E. Stauffer T. J. Neurobiol. 1994; 25: 312-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (126) Google Scholar). To date, little is known about the differences in functional properties between different isoforms, but the few data available on this subject point to such a possibility. Different isoforms can show significant differences in their affinity for calmodulin (45Enyedi A. Filoteo A.G. Gardos G. Penniston J.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 8952-8956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) or in the pattern of phosphorylation (46Strehler E.E. Strehler-Page M.-A. Vogel G. Carafoli E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 6908-6912Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). It is possible that these isoforms might display a differential distribution within the cell, as it has been shown in hepatocytes (47Kessler F. Bennardini F. Bachs O. Serratosa J. James P. Caride A.J. Gazzotti P. Penniston J.T. Carafoli E. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 16012-16019Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In summary, the present study shows that the initiation of the agonist-evoked Ca2+signal is associated with complex changes in the plasma membrane Ca2+transport systems. The increase of [Ca2+]ifollowing the release of Ca2+from the intracellular Ca2+stores rapidly (within 1 s) activates the PM Ca2+extrusion system. The reported differences in the sensitivity to the levels of [Ca2+]iand the different relationships between [Ca2+]iand the rate of extrusion at the two functional poles of the pancreatic acinar cells (lumenal and basal) indicate that the plasma membrane Ca2+ATPase might play an important role in the polarization of the Ca2+response. The maximal “effective” depletion of the intracellular Ca2+pools does not trigger immediately the activation of the Ca2+entry pathway, suggesting the existence of a metabolic step interposed between these two processes. E. C. T. thanks Prof. O. H. Petersen for his continuous support and interest during the stay in Liverpool and V. J. T. for showing and discussing new perspectives.

The B- myb gene belongs to a family of transcription factors that also includes A- myb and c- myb. B- myb is expressed in many cell types including human neuroblastoma cells. Here we demonstrate that B- myb expression is down-regulated during retinoic acid-induced neural and glial differentiation of neuroblastoma cells. This modulation is an early event, is maintained at late times of induction, and is in part regulated at the transcriptional level. Constitutive expression of B- myb prevents retinoic acid-induced neural differentiation as reflected by morphological features and the expression of (or lack of) biochemical markers associated with the undifferentiated phenotype. Furthermore, the expression of antisense B- myb transcripts does not allow the rescue of viable cells, suggesting an important role for B- myb in the survival of neuroblastoma cells. These results indicate that B- myb plays a functional role in the differentiative potential of neuroblastoma cells, raising the possibility that this gene is one of the nuclear regulators in the cascade of events leading to cellular differentiation. The B- myb gene belongs to a family of transcription factors that also includes A- myb and c- myb. B- myb is expressed in many cell types including human neuroblastoma cells. Here we demonstrate that B- myb expression is down-regulated during retinoic acid-induced neural and glial differentiation of neuroblastoma cells. This modulation is an early event, is maintained at late times of induction, and is in part regulated at the transcriptional level. Constitutive expression of B- myb prevents retinoic acid-induced neural differentiation as reflected by morphological features and the expression of (or lack of) biochemical markers associated with the undifferentiated phenotype. Furthermore, the expression of antisense B- myb transcripts does not allow the rescue of viable cells, suggesting an important role for B- myb in the survival of neuroblastoma cells. These results indicate that B- myb plays a functional role in the differentiative potential of neuroblastoma cells, raising the possibility that this gene is one of the nuclear regulators in the cascade of events leading to cellular differentiation. Many transcription factors that normally play a physiological role during development or in adult life can become activated oncogenically upon overexpression or mutation. Several such genes have been characterized with respect to structure, function, and mechanism of action (1Latchman D.S. Eukaryotic Transcription Factors. Academic Press Ltd., London1991Google Scholar). The Myb family of transcription factors includes A- myb, B- myb, and c- myb (2Nomura N. Takahashi M. Matsui M. Ishii S. Date T. Sasamoto S. Ishizaki R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1988; 16: 11075-11090Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar), which are each located on a different chromosome (3Barletta C. Druck T. LaForgia S. Calabretta B. Drabkin H. Patterson D. Croce C.M. Huebner K. Cancer Res. 1991; 51: 3821-3824PubMed Google Scholar, 4Spence M.A. Spurr N.K. Field L.L. Cytogenet. Cell Genet. 1989; 51: 149-165Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Each member of the Myb family is characterized by the presence of DNA-binding and transactivation domains. B- myb, located on the long arm of chromosome X (Xq13) (3Barletta C. Druck T. LaForgia S. Calabretta B. Drabkin H. Patterson D. Croce C.M. Huebner K. Cancer Res. 1991; 51: 3821-3824PubMed Google Scholar), has a DNA-binding domain consisting of three tandemly repeated segments of 51-52 amino acids located near the NH2terminus (5Nakagoshi H. Takemoto Y. Ishii S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 14161-14167Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This region is highly homologous to the corresponding domains of A- myb and c- myb (2Nomura N. Takahashi M. Matsui M. Ishii S. Date T. Sasamoto S. Ishizaki R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1988; 16: 11075-11090Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). Deletion of the second and third repeats completely abolishes the DNA binding-dependent transactivating ability of B- myb (5Nakagoshi H. Takemoto Y. Ishii S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 14161-14167Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A transcriptional activation domain containing a cluster of acidic amino acids and different from the homologous domain of c- myb (6Sakura H. Kanei-Ishii C. Nagase T. Nakagoshi H. Gonda T.J. Ishii S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 5758-5762Crossref PubMed Scopus (276) Google Scholar) is located downstream of the DNA-binding domain of B- myb (5Nakagoshi H. Takemoto Y. Ishii S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 14161-14167Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Unlike c- myb, B- myb does not have a negative regulatory domain, and it does not show negative autoregulatory activity; however, like c- myb, it has multiple nuclear localization signals located near the COOH terminus (5Nakagoshi H. Takemoto Y. Ishii S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 14161-14167Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). c- myb is expressed at high levels in hematopoietic cells, where it plays a major role in the regulation of both normal and malignant hemopoiesis in vitro (7Gewirtz A.M. Calabretta B. Science. 1988; 242: 1303-1306Crossref PubMed Scopus (338) Google Scholar, 8Anfossi G. Gewirtz A.M. Calabretta B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 3379-3383Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar) and in vivo (9Mucenski M.L. McLain K. Kier A.B. Swerdlow S.H. Schreiner C.M. Miller T.A. Pietryga D.W. Scott Jr., W.J. Potter S.S. Cell. 1991; 65: 677-689Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (875) Google Scholar). Several leukemic cell lines express c- myb at high levels that decline during terminal differentiation (10Ramsay R.G. Ikeda K. Rifkind R.A. Marks P.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 6849-6853Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar). In addition, constitutive expression of c- myb blocks Me2SO-induced differentiation of Friend murine erythroleukemia cells (11Clarke M.F. Kukowska-Latallo J.F. Westin E. Smith M. Prochownik E.V. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 884-892Crossref PubMed Scopus (236) Google Scholar). c- myb also appears to play an important role in the proliferation of arterial smooth cells in vivo (12Simons M. Edelman E.R. De Keyser J.-L. Langer R. Rosenberg R.D. Nature. 1992; 359: 67-70Crossref PubMed Scopus (670) Google Scholar). Detectable amounts of c- myb are also found in many tumors of different embryonic origin such as small cell lung carcinoma (13Griffin C.A. Baylin S.B. Cancer Res. 1985; 45: 272-275PubMed Google Scholar), colon carcinoma (14Alitalo K. Vinguist R. Lin C.C. de La Chapelle A. Schwab M. Bishop J.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1984; 81: 4534-4538Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar, 15Torelli G. Venturelli D. Colo A. Zanni C. Selleri L. Moretti L. Calabretta B. Torelli U. Cancer Res. 1987; 47: 5266-5269PubMed Google Scholar), and neuroblastoma (16Thiele C.J. McKeon C. Triche T.J. Ross R.A. Reynolds C.P. Israel M.A. J. Clin. Invest. 1987; 80: 804-811Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). The tissue distribution of B- myb expression is more widespread than that of c- myb and is detectable in stomach, lung, colon, and thyroid carcinoma and neuroblastoma cell lines (2Nomura N. Takahashi M. Matsui M. Ishii S. Date T. Sasamoto S. Ishizaki R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1988; 16: 11075-11090Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). Overexpression of B- myb reduces the growth factor requirements of Balb/c 3T3 fibroblasts (17Sala A. Calabretta B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10415-10419Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar) and bypasses, in part, the p53 growth-suppressive effects in human glioblastoma T98G cells (18Lin D. Fiscella M. O'Connor P.M. Jackman J. Chen M. Luo L.L. Sala A. Travali S. Appella E. Mercer W.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 10079-10083Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). In addition, antisense B- myb oligonucleotides inhibit the proliferation of human leukemic cell lines (19Arsura M. Introna M. Passerini F. Mantovani A. Golay J. Blood. 1992; 79: 2708-2716Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Although B- myb expression, like that of c- myb, correlates with proliferation (17Sala A. Calabretta B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10415-10419Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 20Golay J. Capucci A. Arsura M. Castellano M. Rizzo V. Introna M. Blood. 1991; 77: 149-158Crossref PubMed Google Scholar,), transcription regulation by B- myb appears to be distinct from that of c- myb (21Nakagoshi H. Kanei-Ishii C. Sawasaki T. Mizuguchi G. Ishii S. Oncogene. 1992; 7: 1233-1240PubMed Google Scholar, 22Watson R.J. Robinson C. Lam E.W.F. Nucleic Acids Res. 1993; 21: 267-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). Furthermore, c- myb and B- myb appear to recognize the same DNA sequence, but with different affinities (23Mizuguchi G. Nakagoshi H. Nagase T. Nomura N. Date T. Ueno Y. Ishii S. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 9280-9284Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Although B- myb appears to be involved in cellular proliferation, recent work of Foos et al. (24Foos G. Grimm S. Klempnauer K.-H. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 4619-4629Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar) demonstrating that chicken B- myb inhibits c- myb transactivation of the MIM-1 gene promoter (25Ness S.A. Marknell A. Graf T. Cell. 1989; 59: 1115-1124Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar) raises the possibility that B- myb can act, at least in some instances, as a competitor of c- myb. Despite the wealth of data on B- myb structure and B- myb function as relates to cell proliferation, no evidence exists for its possible involvement in differentiative processes. In this paper, we have investigated the expression and regulation of the B- myb gene during neural and glial differentiative pathways in a neuroblastoma differentiation model. Neuroblastoma is a malignant childhood tumor with a very undifferentiated appearance and is thought to arise from embryonal neural crest tissue that may be arrested at an early stage of differentiation (26Helman L.J. Thiele C.J. Linehan W.M. Nelkin B.D. Baylin S.B. Israel M.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 2336-2339Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). The mechanisms contributing to the onset and progression of neuroblastomas are largely unknown, but nonrandom chromosomal changes suggest the involvement of genetic alterations (27Schwab M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1114: 43-50PubMed Google Scholar). The N- myc oncogene is frequently expressed in advanced neuroblastomas and cell lines (28Kohl N.E. Legouy E. De Pinho R.A. Nisen P.D. Smith R.K. Gee C.E. Alt F.W. Nature. 1986; 319: 73-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar) and undergoes early transcriptional down-regulation when cells are induced to differentiate with retinoic acid (RA) 1The abbreviations used are:RAretinoic acidTESN-tris(hydroxymethyl)methyl-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid. 1The abbreviations used are:RAretinoic acidTESN-tris(hydroxymethyl)methyl-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid.(29Thiele C.J. Reynolds C.P. Israel M. Nature. 1985; 313: 404-406Crossref PubMed Scopus (535) Google Scholar). retinoic acid N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methyl-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid. retinoic acid N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methyl-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid. Like N- myc, c- myb is down-modulated in neuroblastoma upon induction of differentiation (30Thiele C.J. Cohen P.S. Israel M.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 1677-1688Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar), and we recently showed that down-regulation of c- myb expression is associated with inhibition of neuroblastoma and neuroepithelioma cell proliferation (31Raschell G. Negroni A. Skorski T. Pucci S. Nieborowska-Skorska M. Romeo A. Calabretta B. Cancer Res. 1992; 52: 4221-4226PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, to determine the role, if any, of B- myb in the growth and differentiation of neuroblastoma cells, we examined the effects of ablating B- myb expression on the survival of neuroblastoma cell lines and the effects of constitutive expression of B- myb on neural differentiation of neuroblastoma cells. The EcoRI- ScaI region (714 base pairs) spanning nucleotides 941-1655 of the human B- myb cDNA (12Simons M. Edelman E.R. De Keyser J.-L. Langer R. Rosenberg R.D. Nature. 1992; 359: 67-70Crossref PubMed Scopus (670) Google Scholar) was cloned into plasmid pRc/CMV (Invitrogen, San Diego, CA) in the antisense or sense orientation as confirmed by restriction analysis. The full-length cDNA sequence was subcloned in the sense orientation from plasmid pSV-B-myb (17Sala A. Calabretta B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10415-10419Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar) into vector pRc/CMV. The neuroblastoma cell line LAN-5 (32Seeger R.C. Danon Y.L. Rayner S.A. Hoover F. J. Immunol. 1982; 128: 983-989PubMed Google Scholar) was grown in RPMI 1640 medium (Sigma) supplemented with 15% fetal bovine serum (Sigma). The neuroblastoma cell line SK-N-SH (33Biedler J.L. Roffler-Tarlov S. Schachner M. Freedman L.S. Cancer Res. 1978; 38: 3751-3757PubMed Google Scholar) was grown in minimal essential medium (Life Technologies, Inc.) with 10% fetal bovine serum. For cell differentiation experiments, cells were seeded at an initial density of 5 × 103cells/cm2and grown for 16 h before the medium was replaced with fresh medium containing 5 μM all- trans-retinoic acid (Sigma). Medium with RA was then replaced every 3 days. LAN-5 cells were transfected by the calcium phosphate precipitation technique as described (31Raschell G. Negroni A. Skorski T. Pucci S. Nieborowska-Skorska M. Romeo A. Calabretta B. Cancer Res. 1992; 52: 4221-4226PubMed Google Scholar) or by Lipofectin according to the manufacturer's instructions (Boehringer Mannheim). Briefly, cells were seeded at a density of 1.5 × 106cells/dish and 18 h later exposed to a mixture of 10 μg of plasmid DNA and Lipofectin reagent for an additional 18 h. Cells were washed and grown in normal medium for 24 h. G418 (Sigma) was then added at a concentration of 400 μg/ml to the medium, and transfectant clones were isolated 3 weeks later. Total RNA was prepared by acid guanidinium/thiocyanate/phenol/chloroform extraction (34Chomczynski P. Sacchi N. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 162: 156-159Crossref PubMed Scopus (63149) Google Scholar), separated on a formaldehyde-agarose gel using standard procedures (35Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar), and transferred to nylon membranes (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). Filters were hybridized with specific probes using the high stringency protocol suggested by the manufacturer. The EcoRI- ScaI fragment derived from plasmid pSV-B-myb containing the full-length cDNA for human B- myb (17Sala A. Calabretta B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10415-10419Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar) and the 2.1-kilobase XhoI insert of clone HFβA-1 containing the cDNA for human β-actin (36Gunning P. Ponte P. Okayama H. Engel J. Blau H. Kedes L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1983; 3: 787-795Crossref PubMed Scopus (958) Google Scholar) were used as molecular probes in Northern blot analyses. Nuclei for run-on transcription were prepared as described (37Bentley D.L. Groudine M. Nature. 1986; 321: 702-706Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar), with at least 2 × 107cells as starting material. Run-on transcription was carried out with 1 × 107nuclei in the presence of 100 μCi of [α-32P]UTP (DuPont NEN, Bad Homburg, Germany). Five μg of each linearized plasmid was denatured and blocked on a nitrocellulose membrane (Schleicher & Schuell, Dassel, Germany) using a slot blot apparatus. Plasmids used in this experiment were as follows: pSV-B-myb (17Sala A. Calabretta B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10415-10419Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar), a Bluescript plasmid containing the complete cDNA for human c- myb (subcloned in our laboratory); pNB-19-21 containing a fragment spanning the second exon of the human N- myc gene (kindly obtained from Dr. F. Alt, Columbia University); β-actin plasmid HFβA-1 (36Gunning P. Ponte P. Okayama H. Engel J. Blau H. Kedes L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1983; 3: 787-795Crossref PubMed Scopus (958) Google Scholar); and the pVC vector used as negative control. Filters were hybridized for 36 h at 65°C in 10 m M TES, pH 7.4, 0.2% SDS, 10 m M EDTA, 300 m M NaCl, and 5 × 106cpm/ml nuclear RNA from the run-on transcriptions. After hybridization, filters were washed with several changes of 2 × SSC (1 × SSC = 0.15 M NaCl, 0.015 M trisodium citrate) for 2 h at 65°C, incubated at 37°C in 2 × SSC with 10 μg/ml RNase A (Sigma) for 30 min, washed again with 2 × SSC for 1 h at 37°C, air-dried, and exposed to x-ray film. Primers used to confirm integration of the sense and antisense B- myb inserts in transfected cells were as follows: CMV-1, 5′-AATGGGAGTTTGTTTTGGCACCAA-3′, corresponding to nucleotides 699-722 of the pRc/CMV vector; SP6-1, 5′-GCACAGTCGAGGCTGATCAGCGAG-3′, complementary to nucleotides 1020-1043 of the pRc/CMV vector; and B-myb-1, 5′-TGGCATTGCTGGTCAGTGCGGTTA-3′, complementary to nucleotides 313-336 of the human B- myb cDNA sequence (2Nomura N. Takahashi M. Matsui M. Ishii S. Date T. Sasamoto S. Ishizaki R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1988; 16: 11075-11090Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). The oligonucleotide T7-1 (5′-AATACGACTCACTATAGGGAGACC-3′, corresponding to nucleotides 865-888 in the pRc/CMV vector) was used as a specific probe for hybridizations. Polymerase chain reaction analyses were carried out as described (38Szczylik C. Skorski T. Nicolaides N.C. Manzella L. Malaguarnera L. Venturelli D. Gewirtz A.M. Calabretta B. Science. 1991; 253: 562-565Crossref PubMed Scopus (318) Google Scholar). Amplification products were separated on standard agarose gels and transferred to nylon membranes. Filters were prehybridized in 5 × SSC, 1% SDS for 2 h at 47°C. Hybridizations were carried out in 5 × SSC, 1% SDS, 100 mg/ml sonicated salmon sperm DNA, and 107cpm of 5′-end-labeled probe (T7-1) for 16 h at 47°C. After washing in 2 × SSC, 0.5% SDS for 15 min at room temperature and in the same buffer for 15 min at 50°C, filters were exposed in an x-ray cassette with an intensifier screen for 1-4 h. Plasmid pRc/CMV-B-myb containing the full-length sequence of the human B- myb cDNA was linearized with XbaI restriction endonuclease (Promega). In vitro transcription using T7 RNA polymerase (Promega) was carried out according to the manufacturer's instructions, and 1 μg of the B- myb mRNA produced in vitro was translated in a rabbit reticulocyte system (Boehringer Mannheim) in the presence of [35S]methionine (DuPont NEN). Translation products were separated by electrophoresis on a 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gel. The gel was dried and exposed in an x-ray cassette for 2 h. Nuclear extracts from B- myb transfectants, pRc/CMV transfectants, and LAN-5 cells treated for 6 days with RA (5 μM) were prepared as described (39Stein B. Rahmsdorf H.J. Steffen A. Litfin M. Herrlich P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 5169-5181Crossref PubMed Scopus (455) Google Scholar). The protein content of each extract was determined using the protein assay kit II (Bio-Rad). One strand of the myb-specific oligonucleotide MBS-1 (5′-AGAATGTGTGTCAGTTAGGGTGTAGAG-3′) was labeled with [γ-32P]ATP and polynucleotide kinase before annealing to the complementary strand. Mobility shift assays were performed with 6 μg of each nuclear extract or 4 μl of programmed reticulocyte lysate in 40 m M KCl, 15 m M HEPES, pH 7.9, 1 m M EDTA, 0.5 m M dithiothreitol, 5% glycerol, 1 m M MgCl2, and 0.2 μg/μl poly[d(I-C)] (Boehringer Mannheim) in the presence of 0.01 pmol of double-stranded 32P-labeled MBS-1 at room temperature for 20 min. Where appropriate, a 100-fold molar excess of the unlabeled double-stranded MBS-1 or YY1 (5′-CCGAGCCCGCTTCAAAATGGAGACCCTC-3′) oligomer was added to the mixtures as a specific or nonspecific competitor, respectively. Reactions were loaded on a native polyacrylamide gel (5%) run on 0.5 × Tris borate/EDTA (1 × Tris borate/EDTA = 0.090 M Tris borate, 0.002 M EDTA) for 4 h at 140 V at 4°C. The gel was dried and exposed to x-ray film. LAN-5, B- myb transfectants, and pRc/CMV transfectants were metabolically labeled with 100 μCi/ml [35S]methionine (1000 Ci/mmol) for 3 h. Extracts were prepared from 1 × 106labeled cells in 50 m M Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 150 m M NaCl, 5 m M EDTA, 1% Nonidet P-40, 1 m M phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1 μg/ml aprotinin, and 1 μg/ml leupeptin on ice. Immunoprecipitations were carried out essentially as described (40Wenzel A. Cziepluch C. Hamann U. Schurmann J. Schwab M. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 3703-3712Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar) using a specific anti-B-Myb polyclonal antibody (gift of Dr. Robert E. Lewis, University of Nebraska, Omaha, NB) raised in rabbits by immunization with a glutathione S-transferase fusion protein containing amino acids 553-611 of the human B-Myb protein. Cells were seeded at a density of 5 × 103cells/cm2in Labtek chamber slides (NUNC, Naperville, IL) and grown under normal conditions or treated with RA for the appropriate time. After washing in phosphate-buffered saline (137 m M NaCl, 2.7 m M KCl, 4.3 m M Na2HPO4˙7H2O, 1.4 m M KH2PO4), cells were fixed in methanol/acetone (25:75) for 20 min at −20°C and incubated with the appropriately diluted primary monoclonal antibody for 1 h at room temperature. Cells were then extensively washed with phosphate-buffered saline and incubated for 1 h at room temperature with fluoresceinated anti-mouse IgG (Sigma) diluted 1:40. The monoclonal antibodies and relative dilutions used were as follows: anti-vimentin (Sigma), 1:40; anti-glial fibrillary acidic protein (Sigma), 1:400; anti-laminin (Sigma), 1:2000; anti-neurofilament (160 kDa; Sigma), 1:40; anti-collagen type IV (Sigma), 1:500; and anti-S-100 (Boehringer Mannheim), 1:500. B- myb mRNA levels in several neuroblastoma cell lines were determined by Northern blot analysis. Transcripts were detected in all cases (Fig. 1, A and C; data not shown). Since neuroblastoma cells can differentiate toward a neural, Schwann, or melanocytic phenotype depending on the cell line and the inducer (41Tsokos M. Scarpa S. Ross R.A. Triche T.J. Am. J. Pathol. 1987; 128: 484-496PubMed Google Scholar), we investigated whether B- myb mRNA levels might be modulated by differentiative processes. LAN-5 and SK-N-SH cells were treated with RA, which induces predominant neural (42Negroni A. Scarpa S. Romeo A. Ferrari S. Modesti A. Raschell G. Cell Growth & Differ. 1991; 2: 511-518PubMed Google Scholar) and Schwann-like (41Tsokos M. Scarpa S. Ross R.A. Triche T.J. Am. J. Pathol. 1987; 128: 484-496PubMed Google Scholar) phenotypes, respectively. Total RNA was extracted at different times after treatment, separated on a formaldehyde-agarose gel, and transferred to a nylon filter. Filters were hybridized with a B- myb-specific probe, washed, and rehybridized with a probe for β-actin to control the integrity and the amount of each RNA loaded on the gel. After densitometric reading of the autoradiograms and normalization for β-actin mRNA levels, the amount of B- myb mRNA, in arbitrary units, was plotted against the time of RA induction. After RA treatment, B- myb mRNA levels decreased sharply in LAN-5 cells (Fig. 1, A and B), and a moderate, but reproducible decrease was detected in SK-N-SH cells (C and D); B- myb down-regulation occurred as early as 6 h after the beginning of the RA treatment and was maintained at later times in both cell lines (Fig. 1, A-D). To determine whether the down-regulation of B- myb mRNA during RA treatment was due to a transcriptional mechanism, nuclei from untreated and RA-treated (for 6 days) LAN-5 cells were isolated, and in vitro transcription in the presence of [32P]UTP was carried out. The signal intensity for B- myb in filters hybridized with the labeled RNA from untreated LAN-5 cells was >3-fold greater than that detected in filters hybridized with RNA from RA-treated cells (data not shown), demonstrating that the rate of B- myb transcription decreases during RA-induced differentiation. As expected from previous studies (29Thiele C.J. Reynolds C.P. Israel M. Nature. 1985; 313: 404-406Crossref PubMed Scopus (535) Google Scholar, 30Thiele C.J. Cohen P.S. Israel M.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 1677-1688Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar), transcription of N- myc and c- myb was also down-regulated (data not shown). A B- myb fragment (714 base pairs) spanning a region of minimum homology to the other members of the Myb family was cloned in the polylinker region of the pRc/CMV plasmid in the sense or antisense orientation under the control of the cytomegalovirus promoter. Parallel transfections using sense and antisense B- myb plasmids were carried out in LAN-5 cells. After 21 days of selection in the presence of the antibiotic G418, plates were fixed and stained, and the number of resistant clones was counted. In four independent experiments (Table I), the number of resistant clones obtained in the antisense B- myb transfections was significantly lower than that obtained with the sense B- myb transfections, with an average reduction of 79% in the four experiments. Southern blot and polymerase chain reaction analyses of the genomic DNA of the residual antisense B- myb transfectants after antibiotic selection demonstrated rearrangements in the antisense B- myb insert that prevented expression of the antisense B- myb transcript (data not shown), suggesting a counterselection of cells expressing antisense B- myb RNA. The marked reduction in the colony-forming ability of antisense B- myb-transfected cells is in good agreement with the results of similar experiments demonstrating that antisense B- myb RNA or DNA inhibits the proliferation of mouse fibroblasts (17Sala A. Calabretta B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10415-10419Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar) and human hematopoietic cell lines (19Arsura M. Introna M. Passerini F. Mantovani A. Golay J. Blood. 1992; 79: 2708-2716Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, our findings indicate that B- myb is required for the survival of neuroblastoma cells.Table I:Clonogenic assay using an antisense B-myb vector in LAN-5 cells A full-length B- myb cDNA was cloned in the polylinker region of vector pRc/CMV downstream of the cytomegalovirus promoter. The molecular weight of the protein product from the cloned cDNA was verified by in vitro translation (Fig. 2 A). B- myb-transfected LAN-5 cells were grown for 21 days in antibiotic selection medium, and a pool of 60-70 resistant clones was expanded. Pooled transfectants were used in order to maintain the heterogeneity of the parental cell line. Integration of the B- myb construct was monitored by polymerase chain reaction and Southern blot analyses (data not shown). Overexpression of the B- myb transcript in the transfectant clones was analyzed by Northern blot analysis before and after RA treatment for 6 days (Fig. 2 B, lanes 1 and 2). In comparison with transfectants obtained with the pRc/CMV vector (Fig. 2 B, lanes 3 and 4) and with the LAN-5 parental cells (lanes 5 and 6), B- myb mRNA levels were readily down-regulated in control cells, whereas B- myb transfectants expressed B- myb mRNA at high levels, which were even increased after RA induction. Mobility shift assays performed on nuclear extracts from B- myb and pRc/CMV transfectants before and after 6-day RA treatment (5 μM) revealed a specific band in B- myb transfectants (Fig. 2 C, lanes 1 and 2), but not in RA-treated pRc/CMV transfectants (lanes 4 and 5). The B- myb-specific band had a shift pattern similar to that obtained with a B- myb-programmed reticulocyte lysate (Fig. 2 C, lane 7). This result suggests that the protein product of the transfected B- myb construct retains the DNA binding activity, which is still detectable after 6 days of RA induction when endogenous B- myb is down-regulated. Finally, B-Myb protein was immunoprecipitated in B- myb transfectants and controls using a specific rabbit polyclonal antibody to the human B-Myb protein (data not shown). Consistent with the RNA levels, B-Myb protein in B- myb transfectants was more abundant after RA treatment (data not shown). Rates of growth under normal serum conditions were comparable in B- myb transfectants, pRc/CMV controls, and LAN-5 parental cells (data not shown), suggesting that B- myb overexpression does not confer a proliferative advantage to neuroblastoma cells. Nevertheless, it should be pointed out that LAN-5 cells express the endogenous B- myb mRNA at high levels. Morphological analysis of B- myb transfectants and controls induced to differentiate by 6-day treatment with RA revealed the expected differentiation of LAN-5 cells toward a prevalently neural phenotype, with most cells showing long neuritic processes and few cells with a flat morphology (Fig. 3 F). The pRc/CMV transfectants behaved similarly (Fig. 3 E). By contrast, most of the B- myb transfectants showed cell body enlargement with a flat morphology without neuritic processes (Fig. 3 D). To determine whether the morphology of the RA-treated B- myb transfectants correlated with a different biochemical phenotype, these cells were tested for the presence of biochemical markers of differentiation (Fig. 4). Vimentin and neurofilaments, two components of the cytoskeleton that are typical markers of differentiation in neuroblastoma cells (43Shea T.B. Sihag R.K. Nixon R.A. Dev. Brain Res. 1988; 43: 97-109Crossref Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 44Hino T. Sugimoto T. Matsumura T. Horii Y. Inazawa J. Sawada T. Int. J. Cancer. 1989; 44: 286-291Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar), were initially examined. Vimentin was highly expressed in controls and uninduced B- myb transfectants and remained at high levels in RA-treated B- myb transfectants, but was dramatically reduced in RA-treated pRc/CMV transfectants and LAN-5 parental cells (Fig. 4, top panel). Neurofilaments were absent in all uninduced cells under normal growth conditions (data not shown) and were expressed in pRc/CMV controls and LAN-5 cells after RA induction, but not in the B- myb transfectants (Fig. 4, bottom panel). This pattern of intermediate filament expression, together with the morphological data, indicates that RA-treated pRc/CMV transfectants and LAN-5 cells undergo the expected pattern of neural differentiation. By contrast, the high level of vimentin expression and the lack of neurofilaments suggest that neural differentiation is inhibited in RA-treated B- myb transfectants.FIG. 4Top panel, indirect immunofluorescence detection of vimentin. Shown are B- myb transfectants (A and D), pRc/CMV transfectants (B and E), and LAN-5 cells (C and F) under normal growth conditions (A-C) and after 6 days of treatment with RA (D-F). Bottom panel, indirect immunofluorescence detection of neurofilament (160 kDa). Shown are B- myb transfectants (A), pRc/CMV transfectants (B), and LAN-5 cells (C) after 6 days of treatment with RA.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) To determine whether RA-treated B- myb transfectants were induced to enter other differentiative pathways, several components of the extracellular matrix were also investigated: laminin, fibronectin, and collagen type IV, which are produced by neuroblastoma cells and can be modulated during differentiation processes (45Scarpa S. Modesti A. Triche T.J. Am. J. Pathol. 1987; 129: 74-85PubMed Google Scholar); and glial fibrillary acidic protein, which has been described in human brain tumors (46Delpech B. Delpech A. Vidard M.N. Girard N. Tayot J. Clement J.C. Creissard P. Br. J. Cancer. 1978; 37: 33-40Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Finally, the S-100 protein, which is expressed in ∼50% of glial tumors, was also tested (47Weiss S.W. Langloss J.M. Enzinger F.M. Lab. Invest. 1983; 49: 299-308PubMed Google Scholar). Most of the markers analyzed did not change after RA induction in B- myb transfectants and in controls (Table II). The only exception was collagen type IV, a marker of Schwann differentiation, which was increased in SK-N-SH cells (Table II). This marker was moderately increased in B- myb transfectants after RA treatment, but not in pRc/CMV transfectants or in LAN-5 cells. Overall, the phenotypic data indicate the maintenance of many undifferentiated features in B- myb transfectants treated with RA, although they do not rule out the onset of a different, yet not completely defined, differentiative pathway.Table II:Differentiation markers detected by immunofluorescence in B-myb transfectants and controls The induction of differentiation and the commitment to enter a particular pathway are associated with well defined changes in the regulation of gene expression (10Ramsay R.G. Ikeda K. Rifkind R.A. Marks P.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 6849-6853Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar). c- myb, the most extensively studied member of the Myb family, is transcriptionally down-regulated during differentiation of hematopoietic (48Gonda T.J. Metcalf D. Nature. 1984; 310: 249-251Crossref PubMed Scopus (388) Google Scholar) and neuroblastoma (30Thiele C.J. Cohen P.S. Israel M.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 1677-1688Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar) cells. The functional significance of this modulation is suggested by the reported inhibition of Me2SO-induced differentiation in mouse erythroleukemia cells constitutively expressing c- myb (11Clarke M.F. Kukowska-Latallo J.F. Westin E. Smith M. Prochownik E.V. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 884-892Crossref PubMed Scopus (236) Google Scholar). In neuroblastoma, c- myb down-regulation is an early event (30Thiele C.J. Cohen P.S. Israel M.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 1677-1688Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). We have previously demonstrated that c- myb down-regulation inhibits the proliferation of neuroblastoma and neuroepithelioma cells (31Raschell G. Negroni A. Skorski T. Pucci S. Nieborowska-Skorska M. Romeo A. Calabretta B. Cancer Res. 1992; 52: 4221-4226PubMed Google Scholar). We now find that B- myb is expressed in several neuroblastoma cell lines and that B- myb mRNA is down-regulated long before any detectable morphological change when these cells are induced to differentiate along neural and Schwann pathways. Such down-regulation appears to be regulated primarily at the transcriptional level. These findings might be explained in at least three ways. (i) B- myb is involved in the control of proliferative mechanisms that must be down-regulated before differentiation can occur; (ii) B- myb regulates the expression of genes that inhibit differentiation; or (iii) B- myb modulation is a passive event affecting a bystander gene. The last possibility seems unlikely in light of the finding that transfections carried out using an expression vector in which a region of the B- myb gene was cloned in the antisense orientation resulted in a substantially lower number of transfected clones as compared with control transfections (Table I). These data are in agreement with previous studies indicating that B- myb down-regulation inhibits the proliferation of fibroblasts (17Sala A. Calabretta B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10415-10419Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar) and hematopoietic (19Arsura M. Introna M. Passerini F. Mantovani A. Golay J. Blood. 1992; 79: 2708-2716Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) cells. Thus, it appears that B- myb expression is important for the survival of neuroblastoma cells, although the mechanism by which B- myb affects this process remains unclear. Neuroblastoma cells can differentiate in vivo and in vitro toward neural, Schwann, and melanocytic phenotypes, recapitulating the multipotential of neural crest cells from which neuroblastomas derive (41Tsokos M. Scarpa S. Ross R.A. Triche T.J. Am. J. Pathol. 1987; 128: 484-496PubMed Google Scholar). Although many neuroblastoma cell lines show a certain degree of heterogeneity in terms of neurotransmitter expression (33Biedler J.L. Roffler-Tarlov S. Schachner M. Freedman L.S. Cancer Res. 1978; 38: 3751-3757PubMed Google Scholar) and differentiative potential (49Ciccarone V. Spengler B.A. Meyers M.B. Biedler J.L. Ross R.A. Cancer Res. 1989; 49: 219-225PubMed Google Scholar), each cell line has a prevalent behavior in response to differentiation inducers (41Tsokos M. Scarpa S. Ross R.A. Triche T.J. Am. J. Pathol. 1987; 128: 484-496PubMed Google Scholar). LAN-5 cells differentiate to a prevalent neural phenotype by induction with RA. When transfected with a B- myb cDNA, LAN-5 cells overexpressed B- myb. Unlike the parental cell line and control transfectants, B- myb transfectants did not show decreased B- myb expression after treatment with RA. The continuous B- myb expression is due to the expression of the exogenous gene driven by the cytomegalovirus promoter that is not affected by the RA treatment. By contrast, RA appeared to enhance B- myb expression in the B- myb transfectants both at the messenger and protein levels (Fig. 2 B; data not shown). The product of the B- myb construct appears to be functional as nuclear extracts from B- myb transfectants retain the ability to interact with a B- myb-specific binding site even after RA induction (Fig. 2 C). The constitutive expression of B- myb results in the inhibition of neural differentiation as reflected by the enlargement of B- myb transfectant cells, the absence of outgrowing neurites, the maintenance of high level vimentin expression, the lack of neurofilament production, and the moderate increase in collagen type IV expression after 6 days of RA treatment. Such an increase in collagen type IV, which is typical of Schwann-like differentiation, is the only marker of other known differentiative pathways found in RA-treated B- myb transfectants. Thus, it is possible that B- myb-transfected neuroblastoma cells begin a differentiative pathway that is distinct from neural differentiation, but resembles a Schwann-like differentiation. Consistent with this hypothesis, we found only a slight down-modulation of B- myb in SK-N-SH cells differentiating toward a Schwann-like phenotype. Nevertheless, a decrease in B- myb expression under a certain threshold might be required for complete schwannian differentiation. Recently, the mechanism of action of RA on the differentiation of neuroblastoma cells has been analyzed in detail (50Kaplan D.R. Matsumoto K. Lucarelli E. Thiele C.J. Neuron. 1993; 11: 321-331Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar). RA reportedly induces expression of the trkB receptor, which, in turn, renders neuroblastoma cells sensitive to the differentiative action of brain-derived nerve growth factor (50Kaplan D.R. Matsumoto K. Lucarelli E. Thiele C.J. Neuron. 1993; 11: 321-331Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar). However, the nuclear effectors in the signal transduction cascade promoted by the activation of the trkB receptor remain unknown. Based on the results described here, it is tempting to suggest that B- myb is one of the nuclear targets of the differentiation-promoting signal transduced by the trkB receptor. A complete understanding of the process by which a differentiative signal is transmitted to the nucleus is particularly important for the development of effective therapies that may take advantage of the differentiative potential of neuroblastoma cells (51Abemayor E. Sidell N. Environ. Health Perspect. 1989; 80: 3-15Crossref PubMed Scopus (177) Google Scholar). We thank Dr. Robert E. Lewis for the gift of the antibody to B-Myb and Adelma Di Stefano for technical assistance.

Deoxyhypusine synthase is the first enzyme involved in the post-translational formation of hypusine, a unique amino acid that occurs at one position in a single cellular protein, eukaryotic translation initiation factor 5A (eIF-5A). This NAD-dependent enzyme catalyzes the formation of deoxyhypusine by transfer of the butylamine portion of spermidine to the ϵ-amino group of a specific lysine residue in the eIF-5A precursor. Its purification from rat testis was accomplished by ammonium sulfate fractionation and successive ion-exchange chromatographic steps, followed by chromatofocusing on a hydrophilic resin (Mono P). A pI of 4.7 was determined by isoelectric focusing. Amino acid sequences of five tryptic peptides of the pure enzyme did not correspond to any sequences in the protein data banks. The enzyme migrates as a single band on SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis with an apparent monomer molecular mass of ∼42,000 Da. Matrix-assisted laser desorption mass spectrometry gave a monomer mass of 40,800 Da. There is evidence, however, that the active enzyme exists as a tetramer of this subunit. Rabbit polyclonal antibodies to the 42-kDa protein precipitated deoxyhypusine synthase activity. The enzyme shows a strict specificity for NAD. Purified deoxyhypusine synthase catalyzes the overall synthesis of deoxyhypusine and, in the absence of the eIF-5A precursor, catalyzes the cleavage of spermidine.
